[{'document_title': 'Complaints from Liberia', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'It is with unfeigned regret that we have from month to month to bring forward evidence disproving that rose-coloured view of Liberia which it has been so much the fashion to put forward, and in which we ourself have not been blameless. But we fear that the people of Liberia have been injured instead of benefited by that continual laudation of which they have been the objects, and their works in the great path of Christian civilisation the subjects. A few men, really eminent in talent and acquirements—men who might fairly challenge a high position in any civilised state—have brought a renown to her which was only deserved because they individually were worthy. And this has led those who are interested in her welfare to expect too much from her. We have heard of an emigrant population of 15,000 from the United States having brought 600,000 aboriginal natives contentedly under the steadily progressing influences of a Christian civilisation, radiating from Monrovia and Cape Palmas, until we at last believed it. Such accounts as that of the poor women whose liberation was provoked by our notice of their position, and as those which appear in our columns this month, necessarily dispel some of the illusions that have been entertained. But what then? Is Liberia, therefore, a failure? Far from it. It is only the indiscreet eulogies of her friends that have placed her in a false position, and so inflated even the sober and talented men of whom we have been writing with national pride, as to bring her into easily avoidable difficulties; such, for instance, as that with the British Government to which we lately alluded, and that new one which will undoubtedly arise out of the lawless proceedings in the matter of the wreck of the Julia Ellen near Cape Palmas. It is we and other friends who were wrong, in believing it to be possible for this emigrant population of 15,000 United States Africans, not chosen from among the most talented, educated, or wealthy, but principally from among the poor and despised—it is we who were wrong in believing that such a population, whatever its form of government, could bring 600,000 native African heathen under the restraints of civilising influences and Christian laws, or be themselves obedient to them.
**55**', 'last_edit_date': '1870-11-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1870#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.641, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Lagos Mission of the Church Missionary Society', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Dear Sir,—I beg you will allow me space in your columns to give one more instance in support of your frequent endeavours to point out the disadvantages to which the educated Africans on the West Coast are subject by their more favoured European brethren, be they missionaries, merchants, or Government officials. The African is to make no suggestion, or say anything beneficial to his country, when that suggestion or saying appears in any way likely to affect the interest, directly or indirectly, of his European brethren. This is what makes it always difficult to get people in England to believe your assertions in the African Times; because the majority of all European classes on the Coast do all they can to contradict those assertions, and very often some African is employed to assist them in the contradiction. In this case, however, I feel that, the facts being so true and plain, none but very unscrupulous persons in the body concerned will attempt to contradict what I shall here relate.', 'last_edit_date': '1872-11-19', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/30_12_1872#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.659, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Calculated Falsehoods About Liberia', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'There has been an evil spirit at work for many years past, bringing ridicule upon the Republic of Liberia, by obtaining the insertion in the English newspapers of exaggerated statements respecting her. That same spirit is still at work. Under some form, varying from time to time, it has carried on its operations, for the personal benefit of some few individuals, from the period at which dear old Gerald Ralston, who laboured so zealously and so disinterestedly for Liberia, ceased to be her Consul-General in Great Britain. He threw around her poverty (how could she be other than poor?) a halo of respectability which gained for her warm and generous sympathies. The evil spirit has robbed her in great measure of these, and given her, instead thereof, shame and reproach, which are not the less keen and bitter because she does not deserve them. To the machinery which it employed Liberia is under obligation for that public loan, the proceeds of which, spent or intercepted for the most part by her false friends, have left her with a debt of which she is not able at present to pay either interest or principal, and with the odium that necessarily attaches to such impecuniosity. It is a very poor compensation to the Republic that she was toasted and extolled with disgusting inflation at so-called public banquets, which were puffed in newspapers for the self-glorification and other personal advantage of the promoters. For the sake of Liberia we had hoped that all this was at an end. But we were mistaken. We had not adequately estimated the vitality and Protean power of the spirit in question. A few days since we came upon the following in one of the public prints: "It is said that application is to be made to the United States Congress this Session for a grant of $60,000 for the survey of a line of railway from Liberia to the interior of Africa. The object of this scheme is said to be the opening of the Soudan to civilization and commerce. Owing to the extensive purchasing and leasing of lands by the Liberia Coffee Estates Company and others during the past year, the value of land in Liberia has greatly increased, and the facility of a railway into the interior would be of unspeakable value to the Republic." The spirit now goes about incognito. It comes upon us with a modest and retiring "it is said." But the destructive venom is there, and we feel that it is our duty to extract it. We see a great future for Liberia in her coffee industry. The plant with which a bounteous Nature has endowed her is a valuable one, because of its prolific and hardy properties. It has obtained a wide reputation, and we take a deep interest in it, and would not have ridicule thrown upon it, as it was thrown upon the revenue and monetary resources of the Republic, by a defaming exaggeration. We think we know something about what is going on in Liberia, but we certainly have not heard of any Liberia Coffee Estates Company, with any capital to buy up such quantities of the wide-spread public lands of Liberia as to "greatly increase the value" of what is so abundant. The only thing we have heard of, of which we do not know the name, is that some small drafts that were drawn by order in Monrovia on England, as payment for a transferred lease of a few acres, were returned to Liberia dishonoured. And then, as to the introduction—the preface of this astounding announcement of the great increase in the value of lands in Liberia. Somebody is to make a bogus motion in the United States Congress for a grant of $50,000 for the survey of a line of railway from Liberia to the interior of Africa. Liberia has what is looked upon as an illimitable stretch of territory from the sea-coast toward the interior. She has, however, at present only some 16,000 or 17,000 of population really termed Liberians, who are either emigrants from, or the descendants of emigrants from, the United States, although she has a large aboriginal population, which, when civilized, will be a source of great wealth and power to the Republic. She has not really any common public roads worthy the name. Her farm settlements are on the banks of her rivers, and those rivers afford all the facilities of transport that she at present requires. She could not maintain 100 miles of good ordinary road, much less railroad, if she had them. The whole announcement is a bit of superlative nonsense, if it has not some evil aim; and we should not have noticed it but that we are anxious to see an end of that abominable procession of lies which has made Liberia a laughing-stock among all who know something of, and do not love, Africa and her people, and been a cause of pain to those who do earnestly desire to see her countries march steadily in the track of civilization and Christianity to developed productiveness and wealth. What Liberia has need of is capital, and an increase of civilized industrial population; and when she has these, she will no doubt gradually spread out her arms toward the interior. She wants, too, after all that has happened concerning her and her representatives in England, to have some one of established reputation here to speak with authority in her name, and who may be applied to with confidence in such matters as this of the wonderfully increased value of her lands through the operations of some extremely wealthy company, which we can only at present think of as about as mythical as is the greatly increased value which it is said to have induced.', 'last_edit_date': '1878-05-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1878#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.645, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Another Danger than Heathenism for Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Rev. Alex. Crummell, M.A. (Cambridge), writes in a recent letter from Liberia:—

"Our children ought not to be allowed to grow up in ignorance of letters. In absolute ignorance they cannot grow up; for, alas! they are learning all evil things from the heathen. And what will the next generation be? Moreover, we have well nigh at hand another and, I think, as dread a danger impending. The Roman Catholics in a very brief time will be in our midst, with large charities and profuse gifts of money. Ten years have passed since they sent word they intended to occupy Liberia, and now the news comes to us again from Sierra Leone. Already have they seduced some few Liberians, sojourning at Freetown; and two, I hear, have been re-baptized by them. Here they will make an easy prey of our people, for, alas! such a thing as catechising is but seldom known in Liberia. I am speaking of Christians in general in this country. Our religion is too generally one of excitement, and too often marred with

the taint of Antinomianism; and the training of the people has been so very much neglected that there are very few who can give a reason of the faith they profess; very few who have ever read their Bibles. It is these things which fill me with anxiety on the expected approach of the Romanists to our communities. At Sierra Leone they have established themselves at Freetown with power and influence, and are now spreading out to Waterloo, Regent and other old stations. Just so would they do here."', 'last_edit_date': '1868-10-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1868#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.675, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—The *African Times* of November 1st contains a letter having reference to our work here. While the said letter appears to be written by one who appreciates my efforts to benefit the Gambia, I must, in justice to the Rev. Mr. Adcock, and in the interest of truth, openly deny the veracity of several of the statements it contains, and request you to publish my entire disapproval of its appearance in your paper. I do not know "Wesleyan," but if he knew more of the internal work of our Mission, he would not give me the honour due to another.—Yours, &c.,', 'last_edit_date': '1878-02-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1878#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.671, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Mission Work at the Cameroons', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'in the printing-office are not recognized by the other missionaries, excepting the one under whose direction he labours. Why so? Because ministerial discord and dissension are at the bottom of it. One of England's greatest philanthropists said that, "If Africa is to be evangelised she must be evangelised by her sons." Of course, not exclusive of the aid of England's sons, but a black ministry with one or two whites at its head will be found more effectual than otherwise. The following fact will be seen to give much force to this suggestion. White missionaries are obliged very frequently to go to Europe to recruit their health, no doubt at a heavy cost to the Society, to say nothing of the disadvantage that their stations must suffer owing to their absence, which sometimes is rather protracted. The two oldest missionaries in the mission now, excepting the superintendent, are blacks. One has been out twenty-five years, and the other twelve years, yet they have not once had occasion to go to Jamaica to recruit their health; whereas the whites, without exception, have found it necessary to go to England, some at rather short intervals. Should the question be asked, "Why are not some youths taken out of the day-schools at Cameroons and Victoria, and sent to England, or even to the Sierra Leone Grammar School, to be trained up as teachers and native preachers?" or "Why cannot a boarding school be established at Victoria?" the answer, no doubt, will be, "Oh, it will cost the Society a very large amount of money." Undoubtedly true; but isn't it a generally acknowledged fact, and don't we ourselves know it from experience, that it is always best, in the long run, to purchase things at wholesale prices? A wholesale purchase may entail on the purchaser a heavy expense at once, but in the end it will be found far cheaper than purchasing at retail prices. Victoria is a cheap place—food and fish so very plentiful that the missionaries up here send all the way down there very often to buy food, which requires only tobacco and salt to buy it with, and which can be had every day. Victoria being a market town, a boarding school once established there, with competent teachers and a constant supply of books and other requisites to be sold to the pupils of the school, will, in the course of a few years, supply the different stations in the mission with young men capable of taking schools and churches under their own care, and in this way the work of evangelisation will be more surely and steadily carried on, and the Society's labours and expenses be more than amply rewarded; also, in course of time, the school will become a self-supporting school.', 'last_edit_date': '1869-07-28', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1869#article-21', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.645, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Sir,—We, the inhabitants of Duke Town, Old Town, and Creek Town, are glad to see that your life is still prolonged by the Almighty Power, and that your valuable paper is still distributed along the West Coast of Africa.

We are sorry to have to denounce the conduct of one of our pastors here, whose conduct is so disgraceful amongst us and the Europeans here, for we see clearly that the other pastors are afraid to report him to their Board at home. We are glad to receive the good tidings of salvation by Jesus Christ in our countries, but to send a man to teach us evil ways is not good. We must now put the conduct of the person we are writing about before you and all who are interested about West Africa. He goes on board the hulks to hold service on Sundays, and before the service is over he is quite drunk. This has been several times, and when the supercargoes found him to be such a rev. drunkard, they put a stop to him. But still he will not leave going on board. We often find him travelling along the beach at ten o'clock at night for a boat to go on board the shipping to get himself drunk, and when he returns the next morning there must be two Krooboys beside him—one on his right hand and another on his left—to carry him home. Mr. Editor, this is the fact we are saying. When he gets home he flogs his wife, who is obliged to run to some neighbour. Shall such a man dwell amongst us, Mr. Editor? A man who calls himself a pastor buying trade gin and rum to put into his house to treat friends! Can

Africa be evangelized by such men? We must get rid of this man from Old Calabar, for his conduct is very bad. In the first place, his conduct is bad to white men, as well as to us here; he is a rash man—no Spirit of God in him, not the least. He called himself a doctor, too; but if any of us go to him for medicine, he refuses to give us any, and, at the same time, he objects to other doctors attending us. This he did to two of us; he refused to let Dr. Spearce attend two of our boys, and through this they are dead. Who can look upon such a man and call him a man of God? He only came out to deceive the Home Board and to get pay—150l. a-year. We had sooner not have a church than to have him with us. The dogs cannot go under his sermons; they have no taste to man or to beast. Mr. Editor, we have one good man here—the Rev. Mr. Anderson. This dear, good old man has plenty to do, for he does all the work here. What other pastor could be able to preach eight times in the week through the year? Very few. Mr. Editor, leave not a single line out, as this is written to your paper, and we shall be glad to see it there. This is the first opportunity we have had to correspond with you, and we shall be glad to tell you always of our country.—We beg to remain, yours, Mr. Editor,", 'last_edit_date': '1874-08-09', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/30_09_1874#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.653, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BRITISH ADMINISTRATION IN WEST AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'West Africa is one of the richest mineral regions on the planet, and England has been given an entrance to it for the purpose of spreading a civilisation and Christianity that will not do harm to the cause of the Gospel or bring disgrace on morality. The Mohammedan traders on the west coast of Sierra Leone, when asked where they get their precious metals and fine work, turn round and point to the north-east—Segoo, Bambara. Why have we not been in Bambara years ago? A light railway should have been run up to the north-east. The French are outstripping us along the line, and they deserve to; for St. Louis alone is an example of their superiority to us as colonisers. They are tapping all that rich region while we remain inert.

West Africa has, from interested motives, been represented as unhealthy for Europeans. This illusion is being rapidly dispelled by disinterested travellers. The Englishman, through unhealthy habits, may dig his own grave even in England, as so many thousands do annually. Besides, were London as innocent of sanitary arrangements as Freetown, it would soon become the white man's grave in grim reality. A man unaddicted to drink and gluttony may live, and does live, an enjoyable life in West Africa; he enjoys it so much that, like Emin Pasha, he refuses to be rescued. Officers and others have told me they preferred being out there for a time, not only because they liked the life, but because "dear old Cox" has been able to transfer the balance of their account from the debit to the credit side.

West Africa is the coming country; it teems with wealth; it is within easy distance of this country, and can be brought within six days of the London market if necessary. All that we require to do is to get rid of the drink, open out the country as honest people, and make room for our surplus population, from the nobleman's son down to the humblest artisan and labourer. There is fibre there for our manufacturers of Lancashire and Yorkshire; there is gold, silver, copper, coal, precious stones, ivory, india-rubber, nitrate, indigo, antimony, guano, palm oil, kola, ebony, mahogany, gum-copal, potash, ginger, gum, iron, farinaceous foods, dye woods, tanning material, spices, coffee, tobacco, cocoa, cotton, and other produce. When we look to India and Australia we are struck with wonder at the marvellous material and moral progress which is the outcome of a century of British rule. But with Africa—the West Coast especially—the result is far different; in spite of the great extension of European influence in that portion of the world, it is doubtful whether the Native, quâ Native, is really the better for what has been brought before him during the last hundred years. Not that it is his fault; at least, entirely. When Great Britain set herself to the task of redeeming the great debt which she, above all nations, owed to Africa—for was not she the originator of the shameful Slave Trade?—she was prompted doubtless by the best of motives, but did not fully appreciate the difficulties of the task she then undertook. To repair the wrong she herself had inflicted there was but one sure course—to devote her best. Poor widows and orphans, and others, are thus deluded into ‘Coffee Companies,’ &c., which die still-born, and the funds invested vanish. And then these people operate in Liberia, showing the people shortcuts to fortune, unsettling their ideas, absorbing their earnings, and preventing steady industry. But, of course, the golden harvest turns out to be an ‘airy nothing,’ born in the fertile brains of these friends, whence ‘gaudy shapes, thick and numberless as the gay motes that people the sunbeams,’ continually

Half Cavalla, October 24, 1875.

Sir,—I have sent you with this papers containing the history and results of the present war between us (Grebos), part of Kroo people, and the Americo-Liberians. Liberia, in its wide sense, means the Monrovians and the colonists of Cape Palmas; but, to give you a full understanding, you will note that the present war with the Monrovians and colonists of Cape Palmas entirely excludes the aborigines of the Monrovia territory; for Monrovia was first settled before Maryland County (Palmas). The former was settled in 1821, and the latter in 1834, and both became one in the war between the colonists and the aborigines of Cape Palmas in 1856-7. Whether the Americo-Liberians have bought the countries of the Kroos under the Monrovians, we cannot tell or have anything to do with; but we are after our native land, which they in pretence say they have bought from us.

The Liberians never bought our land, and neither do they conquer us by war. In the war of 1856-7 we conquered them in the battle of Shepherd Lake, when their cannons, drums, and other best fire-arms were taken from them, but were freely restored by us when they sent a white flag to our king, which ended the war.

Again seeing themselves improved from the advantage of the country, and with a boasting and proud heart, by reason of new ammunition procured from the United States Government (whether by purchase or present, I do not know), they foolishly declared this present war. They hate our young men, who are taught by P. E. Mission; they hate the missionaries themselves because they teach the Gospel.

I wonder at what the Americo-Liberians used to say to the king of this place—that whenever they have any war with us they would doubtless receive assistance from the English, Americans, French, Germans, &c., to drive us away from the beach! To these statements I particularly call your attention, to know whether it is true or not. What have I taken from the English? Whom have I killed belonging to the Americans? What have I ever stolen from the French? and what German have I forcibly sent away from my land?

Did not I and the whites fight together for the purpose of setting slaves at liberty? Did not my blood and that of the white lie together in one place, especially in the last Ashanti war? Did I ever practise the slave-trade? Am I not the white man's friend, then? Mr. Editor, as my hand is short to show to the world my grief, I do beg your assistance on my behalf and the behalf of my people.

Please correct every mistake in spelling, omission of words, &c., as English is not our native tongue.—Your humble servant,  
King Wea.

Morgan.)", 'last_edit_date': '1875-10-24', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1876#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.639, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BRITISH MISRULE IN WEST AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Probably it will be said that this picture is grossly exaggerated—a mere caricature.* But the fact remains that it is an Englishman who speaks, and thereby condemns his own country for the century of misrule under which Sierra Leone groans. There are thousands of native Africans who are in all respects the equals of the most cultured Europeans; and the average West African is not deficient in those qualities the need of which would prevent his governing himself; but subject to the shocking influences which are all around, is it to be wondered at that he sinks to a lower level than his entirely uncivilised neighbour in the far interior?', 'last_edit_date': '1891-03-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_03_1891#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.648, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE "AFRICAN TIMES" AND THE AUTHORITIES AT LAGOS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We find that complaint is made at Lagos of the article in our February number, relative to the non-delivery in Lagos of our journal of the 23rd November. We are accused of undue and intemperate haste in charging any of the colonial authorities with the suppression of our paper on that occasion, and condemned for writing as if there was a certainty about it, when there not only was no certainty at all, but, moreover, when the thing really had not taken place. We are told we ought to have waited, and made proper inquiry, and then we should have found there was no truth whatever in the statement. We do not think we were unduly hasty. We did not act upon a single testimony. We received letters from several of our subscribers complaining of the alleged fact; and it was, we believe, the first time such a thing had occurred; and there did happen to be in the November number, also for the first time, certain matter which might not be quite agreeable to the authorities. The papers had been duly
**125**

posted in England, and the papers were not duly delivered in Lagos. We were therefore justified in writing on the supposition that they had been purposely withheld from our subscribers. And what is now the explanation we have indirectly received? "The greater portion of the November number of the 'African Times' arrived in December, and the two numbers for November and December were delivered together to the various subscribers," i.e., we presume, if words mean anything, that the November papers which arrived in Lagos in December, were detained at the Post-office there until the December papers arrived in January, and then the papers of the two months were delivered to the subscribers at the same time. We can only say in reply that under such circumstances our subscribers who did not receive the November papers in December were fully justified in believing that they had been suppressed, and in writing to us to that effect. In order to avoid the recurrence of similar unfounded charges against any of the Lagos authorities, we therefore beg respectfully to suggest that they will do well at all times to deliver the papers immediately on their arrival.', 'last_edit_date': '1866-05-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1866#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.646, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}]

hh: Religious institutions, particularly Methodist and Baptist churches, were instrumental in organizing and supporting the emigration movement and resettlement of African Americans in Liberia and West Africa, highlighting the significant role of faith-based groups in the African diaspora.
result: The observations from both the "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles collectively underscore the significant role of religious institutions, particularly Methodist and Baptist churches, in organizing and supporting the emigration movement and resettlement of African Americans in Liberia and West Africa. The textbook highlights the involvement of the African Methodist Episcopal (AME) and African Methodist Episcopal Zion (AME Zion) churches, along with the National Baptist Convention (NBC), in deploying black missionaries to Africa during the colonial period. These churches established missions in Liberia and other parts of Africa, with the AME Zion Church setting up roots in Liberia as early as 1878. Figures like Daniel Coker and Lott Cary, associated with these religious movements, championed the emigration tradition. The AME Church's symposium on the policy of colored Americans toward Africa and the involvement of black church leaders in promoting emigration to Liberia further emphasize the instrumental role of faith-based groups in the African diaspora. Similarly, The African Times articles highlight the active participation of the African Methodist Episcopal Church and the Baptist Church in the emigration efforts, noting individuals like Rev. James O. Hayes and the purchase of the barque Azor for the exodus movement. The Methodist Mission's agricultural efforts in Liberia, such as coffee shipments to the United States, indicate their broader involvement in the region's development. However, both sources acknowledge that the emigration movement was not solely driven by religious institutions, as other organizations, such as the American Colonization Society, and figures like Marcus Garvey also played significant roles, suggesting a broader coalition supporting the movement.

Cain, in the Missionary Record, published in Charleston, S.C., makes an earnest appeal for twenty thousand dollars for missions in this country, and also in Hayti and Liberia, in West Africa, to be conducted by the African Methodist Episcopal Church.'}, {'id': 3348, 'article_title': 'GOOD TIDINGS FOR LIBERIA.', 'full_section_title': 'GOOD TIDINGS FOR LIBERIA.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1877#article-1', 'issue_date': '01_08_1877', 'content': 'There is a movement among the Africans in the United States toward Liberia sufficiently marked to have induced the New York Correspondent of the London daily paper, the _Standard_, to give his version of it. He says there is a _strong feeling_ in favour of moving over to Liberia; that "in Charleston alone 2,500 negroes are already enrolled to go to Liberia, and in the State of South Carolina, up to the present time, _thirty thousand_ are enrolled. A grand mass meeting was held in Charleston on the 4th July, at which are reported to have been present between ten and fifteen thousand negroes." "In the churches—generally Methodist and Baptist—which are organized separate from the whites, these movements are generally fostered. All these negro churches have had discourses from their pastors upon this question, and one church is said to have followed its pastor in his zeal to go so far as to have enrolled every one of its members upon the emigrant books."

We purpose alluding further to this great movement in our next. We hope it is not a mere momentary fever, but a settled purpose of emigration, or rather return, to Africa. There has been a general subscription to furnish the funds for three persons to go to Liberia, inspect, and report. We hope they will go back with an account that will bring an influx to the Republic.

We consider that our indefatigable friend, Mr. J. C. The barques Liberia and Monrovia, built expressly for passenger and freight trade with Western Africa, sailed from New York, May 22 and 29 respectively, with valuable cargoes and 136 emigrants for Liberia. Dr. Saul of Philadelphia, Pa., writes to this office that he addressed the coloured emigrants just before their departure—"with whose respectable and intelligent appearance he was much pleased."'}, {'id': 4533, 'article_title': 'THE GAMBIA, WEST AFRICA.', 'full_section_title': 'THE GAMBIA, WEST AFRICA.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1883#article-2', 'issue_date': '01_01_1883', 'content': 'Contributions towards the annual expenditure of the missions, or donations for the establishment of the mission stations, will be thankfully received by the Rev. George Nicol, Church Missionary House, Salisbury Square, E.C.; the Rev. R. C. Billing, The Rectory, Spitalfields, London, E.; H. G. Malaher, Esq., Missionary Leaves Association, 5, Tyndale Place, Islington, London, N.; Miss Lanfear, Avington Manor, Hungerford; Miss Langley, Priory Cottage, Wallingford; and Miss L. A. Large, 1, Newland Villas, Gloucester.

N.B.—It may be well, perhaps, to mention that the Rev. George Nicol is a son-in-law of Bishop Crowther. He was educated at the Fourah Bay Institution at Sierra Leone, where he was afterwards a teacher. He then spent some time at the Church Missionary College, Islington, and was ordained by Bishop Blomfield in the year 1849. After serving twenty years, first as a missionary and afterwards as a native pastor at Sierra Leone, he accepted in 1879, with the sanction and encouragement of the Church Missionary Society, his present important post at the Gambia.'}]

[{'document_title': 'Exodus of American Africans for Liberia', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The *Philadelphia Evening Telegraph* of February 23, 1878, has the following:—

"The African Exodus.—The Movement an Earnest One—A Vessel Purchased.—Henry M. Turner, LL.D., the Business Manager of the Publication Department of the African Methodist Church, has just returned to this city from a tour of several months in South Carolina, Georgia, and other Southern States. He informs us that the Liberia exodus movement has taken hold of freedmen of energy, and in some cases of considerable pecuniary ability. He found the people in Charleston jubilant in view of the purchase of the barque Azor for the furtherance of the exodus movement. The money has been raised entirely by the coloured people. The President of the society, Rev. B. F. Porter, is now in Boston, and will sail, in a few days, in the

vessel for Charleston, where several hundred freedmen are now awaiting the arrival of the vessel. One hundred emigrants from Abbeville district, in South Carolina, with others, are spoken of as persons of industry and excellent moral character. Dr. Turner, of this city, is to deliver the oration at the dedication of the vessel to the work of African civilization and evangelization. Dr. Turner is himself a native of South Carolina, and was formerly a member of the Legislature of Georgia. He states that at the recent meeting of the South Carolina Conference of the African Methodist Church, at Georgetown, S.C., Bishop Brown appointed a minister to go with the expedition to Liberia as a representative of the African Methodist Church."

**"GOING BACK TO AFRICA."**—Telegrams from Charleston, S.C., say the coloured people of that State are taking a great interest in the Liberian Exodus Association, the object of which is to take coloured emigrants from the United States to Liberia, Africa. A ship is about to start from Charleston, carrying 250 coloured passengers for Liberia, and hundreds more are waiting until transportation can be furnished them. They are to be provided with comfortable quarters in Monrovia by the Liberian Government until they are removed to the lands which are to be given to them at the rate of twenty-five acres for each head of a family and ten acres for each male adult. They intend settling in the north-west portion of the territory. It is claimed that over 160,000 people are enrolled to go when occasion offers, and that if transportation could be obtained, at least one-half of the coloured population of the State would go, so thoroughly have they been worked up on the subject. The feeling is carefully cultivated and wide-spread among them that it is their mission to return to Africa and endow their brethren there with the civilization and enlightenment which they have acquired, as the phrase goes, 'during their captivity and bondage.' No white man has any connection with the scheme."', 'last_edit_date': '1878-02-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1878#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.681, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'CANNOT ABEOKUTA SEND THE MONEY?', 'section_title': '', 'content': "DESIRE TO RETURN.—Among the services during the Baptist anniversaries at Macon, Georgia, in May last, it is stated that the address of Rev. A. D. Phillips to the second Baptist Church of coloured people was peculiar, and indicative of a new era. Mr. Phillips has been several years in Yoruba, in Central Africa, and very successful as a missionary. During the war the natives aided in his support, as in that of other missionaries; while also on a visit to England he obtained considerable subscriptions. He returned to this country to recruit some months ago. A few Sabbaths ago, in addressing the coloured Baptist Church in Mobile, Alabama, he quoted, as usual, the Lord's Prayer in Yoruba, when several men and women in the crowd fairly shouted with joy. After service some twenty-five or thirty men and women came pressing through the aisles to meet him, and addressed him in Yoruba. On inquiry, he found they were native Yorubans, of a better class of negroes, brought to Savannah some ten years ago by the Wanderer. A party of Dahomey warriors, on a slave-hunt, had seized them when on a trading excursion and carried them to the coast, where they were shipped on the Wanderer. These people have kept themselves separate from intermarriage and intercourse with the other coloured people, and since their emancipation have hoped some day to get to their home. They have become Christians, and united with the Baptist Church. They have been saving up money to get home, and begged Mr. Phillips to take them.—*African Repository.*", 'last_edit_date': '1870-01-24', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/24_01_1870#article-20', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.674, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE CHRISTIAN CIVILIZATION OF AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Emancipated slaves, or the children of such slaves, now constitute a Christian nation on the coast of Africa, with Christian laws, institutions, and teaching—a state formed after the pattern of that country in which they and their forefathers were in bondage, and where they learned the rudiments of that Christian civilization which they cannot fail to propagate until it embraces and absorbs a great variety of tribes and peoples. And, as if to afford an additional evidence of the correctness of our belief and views, there now comes to us from the United States—from that Virginia which was the chief seat of the suppressed Government of the States which seceded from the Union, but which have now again entered it—intelligence of the approaching departure of a band of voluntary emigrants for Liberia, seemingly the vanguard of a more extensive emigration. In the *Times* of Friday, November 3, the following appeared among the intelligence from the United States: "A large number of negroes living in Virginia have petitioned their former masters for money to help them to go to Liberia. It is said 150 of them will start for that colony on November 1. They say: 'We expect to leave this city on November 1 next, for our fatherland, and leave you all for no reason but the one above mentioned; none of us will carry with us the prejudices and ill-will that might arise from our being held in bondage by you, as your slaves. We know that you have been our best friends, and we feel it now the more, though we are free. You all know the peculiar situation the termination of the late war has left us in; so, therefore, we call upon you to aid us in our enterprise. We know your generous and sympathetic hearts will not let you stand aloof from us in our endeavours to do good for ourselves and people. Some of us are capable of conveying ideas of the mechanical arts; some can unfold to them, in our poor way, the marvellous light of the Gospel, and point them the way to God. We are not going to try to educate the people of Liberia, because from what we can learn they are far our superiors in intelligence, wealth, and learning; but Africa generally. Some of us have a good common education, which we think will be of value to those who have not.'', 'last_edit_date': '1865-11-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1865#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.663, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'AFRICA AND THE JUBILEE FUND OF THE WESLEYAN MISSIONARY SOCIETY', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Wesleyan Missionary Society have raised a large Jubilee Fund at Leeds, and other towns. We are glad to see that a prominent place is given to Africa and her children in the contemplated disposal of it. The following is from the monthly organ of the Society: "It was deeply felt by the Committee that the hope for the evangelization of Africa must mainly rest on the employment of a native agency. The difficulties of the African languages form a barrier to the free labour of English missionaries among the African nations, and the climate of large portions of that vast continent is very unfavourable to European health and life. At the same time, on every mission in Western and in Southern Africa there have been found native converts who have been deemed suitable to be employed as teachers among their countrymen. Some of these have been honoured of God with great success. It is desired that means may be provided for the training and employment of a much larger number of native African agents; and that at important centres, hereafter to be selected, schools or institutions should be formed for that purpose, to be commenced and sustained by an appropriation from the Jubilee Fund. In contemplation of the vastness of the field of labour in Africa it will be admitted that a large amount may with propriety be consecrated to this service.', 'last_edit_date': '1863-11-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1863#article-23', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.66, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Wesleyan Missions in West Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We are sure the following extracts from the report presented at the recent Anniversary Meeting will be perused with interest by our readers:—

"For the Sierra Leone District the year has been eventful. Fire, sword, and pestilence have alike tested the faith of pastors and people. In Sierra Leone the number of conversions has been larger than for some years. In the Wilberforce Circuit, among the new converts is the son of a Mohammedan priest. In the Limbah country the Church grows in numbers, intelligence and piety. Mr. Booth has three native catechists, of whom one is conversant with Arabic. Educational work in the District is progressing. Quarterly meetings have been formed, and Circuit stewards this year for the first time took part in the business of the District Meeting. In the Gambia section earnest efforts are being put forth in order to use more effectually the waterway of the Gambia river, and thus really to take hold of the population in the interior. The people themselves have a mind both to give and to work, and so to carry the Gospel inland, to meet the power of Mohammedanism which is advancing from the interior.

"For the Gold Coast District with its several sections, this is the year of Jubilee. Just fifty years ago the Rev. Joseph R. Dunwell began the Methodist Mission at Cape Coast. There are now in West Africa nearly 14,000 members, whilst thousands more have safely found their rest. The Jubilee is to be celebrated by special gatherings, and also by special gifts for the consolidation of existing missions and for extension in the regions beyond. A series of most enthusiastic meetings have already been held in the Cape Coast section of the District, and a sum of £10,000 has been promised to the Jubilee Fund. This result has filled us with wonder and gladness; and, best of all, in connexion with the same meetings, scores of the heathen have renounced their heathenism and turned from dumb idols to serve the living and true God.

"The mission to Ashanti has entered upon a new era. After patient waiting for more than forty years, the door has been opened and the Gospel may now be freely preached. Kumasi, and other towns equally notorious for their human sacrifices, are now occupied. In all of them mission schools and premises have been provided by the people at their own cost. The kings themselves all regularly attend the open-air service.

"In every part of the District the work is extending, and agents are wanted. This is the day of Africa's visitation, and very bright are the hopes which urge onward to their duty the Churches of Christ at home.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1885#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.671, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African-Aid Society and the Missionary Societies', 'section_title': '', 'content': "We alluded last month to the intimate connexion which must necessarily exist between the work of the African-Aid Society and that of the various missionary societies which are striving for the introduction and spread of Christianity in native Africa. There are two great objects kept constantly in view in the operations of our society—the increase of a civilising and humanising commerce, and the displacement of pagan superstitions, with all their frightful adjuncts of horrors, by that Christianity without which no true elevation and real civilization is possible to any people. So far as we ourselves are personally concerned, we do not for a moment hesitate to say that in all our efforts, the spread of the Redeemer's kingdom upon earth is the great object for which we labour, and that we regard the commercial adjuncts only as secondary, though, in our opinion, indispensable to the rapid progress of Gospel truth among the debased populations of Africa.", 'last_edit_date': '1864-11-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1864#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.669, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'EMIGRATION FROM THE UNITED STATES TO LIBERIA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The movement for emigration to Liberia seems to be progressing. In the *Charleston Missionary Record* we read that the spirit of emigration is greater among the coloured people of the United States than was ever before known. The Charleston "Liberian Exodus Association" and the North Carolina "Freedmen's Liberian Emigration Society" are both gaining strength and showing great activity. The "American Colonization Society," which has been for so many years engaged in the good work, does not altogether approve of this proposed hasty colonization. It has sent out, in January, seventy negroes, composed principally of families from Mississippi, North Carolina, Virginia, Maryland, and Pennsylvania. These poor people subscribed 1,000 dollars toward the expense of their voyage. The vessel, named the "Liberia," is expected to be about forty days on her voyage, and takes the emigrants at fifty dollars each, children half fare. On the arrival of the vessel at Monrovia, it is said that ex-President D. B. Warner, now Vice-President Elect of the Republic, will take charge of the six months' reserved store of provisions.

Sherwood Capps, educated at Raleigh, North Carolina, sailed for Liberia, in West Africa, from New York, on Wednesday, January 2. He sent a petition to Congress for aid to send coloured emigrants to Liberia. The petition was presented by Hon. Mr. Garfield. Maban Merrill, with his wife and children, of Raleigh, N.C., sailed on the same vessel.

A. L. Sanford and C. H. Hicks, who were appointed Commissioners to visit Liberia in behalf of freedmen in Arkansas, started on Wednesday, January 2. They left Helena, Arkansas, December 24.

A. M. Page, educated at Fiske University, in Nashville, Tennessee, sailed for Liberia, in Africa, from New York, on Wednesday, January 2. Rev. Samuel J. Mills, the noble missionary pioneer, was the first Congregationalist minister who visited Africa to secure a place for coloured colonists from America.', 'last_edit_date': '1878-03-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1878#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.67, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Wesleyan Methodist Extension in West Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'I am sure that all readers will be glad to know that Methodism is not in any way losing ground in Western Africa; rather are we trying to obey the once Presidential motto—"An advance all along the line." Certainly, if there are occasions and opportunities for advancement anywhere they are here in this field of arduous and perilous toil. It was my good fortune to be present at the laying of the memorial stones of the new Hoare Memorial School Chapel at Yaba, not far from Lagos; and thinking that an account of such an eventful ceremony would interest all whose sympathies are with our Foreign Missions, I will endeavour to describe what was to me a time of great joy and blessing. Yaba is a little village situated on the mainland, and about six miles from the island of Lagos. The stone-laying ceremony attracted a great number of spectators, and the day was a glorious one. *The Lagos Echo*, in referring to the service, says: "From early dawn boats and canoes might be seen merrily plying the lagoon with their human freight all bound for Ebute Metta. With glorious weather, and all nature around us keeping as it were a gay holiday, we realised most vividly, as we walked from the landing-place through a lovely piece of country on to the village of Yaba, the truth of Charles Kingsley's epigram—'God made the country, man made the town.' Arriving at our destination we found the quiet village all instinct with life, astir with excitement, and merry with the voices of holiday-seekers. The service began about 9.30 a.m., the audience numbering about 500. The members of the Olowoghowo Church choir were present, and, under the management of Dr. Obasa, rendered two special anthems in magnificent style." In the centre of the church site was erected a large booth, covered in with beautifully green palm-leaves, and neath this friendly shelter from the sun's powerful and insidious rays the preliminaries connected with the function were gone through. Hymns were sung and prayers offered in Yoruba, and then the pastor, the Rev. J. H. Samuel, in a few pithy remarks, introduced us to the business of the day. Mrs. Bryan Roe, our chairman's estimable wife, laid the first stone in the name of the Wesleyan Missionary Society, and beneath was deposited a bottle containing a copy of the "Wesleyan Missionary Notices," and a copy of *At Home and Abroad* for September 1895, some coins of the year 1895, and a few cowries. To quote again from *The Lagos Echo*: "The second stone was laid by Mrs. Dawudu; the bottle deposited contained a short memorial sketch of the late Mr. Hoare, concluding with the following interesting paragraph: 'This church is erected to the memory of Mr. T. C. Hoare, who, during his lifetime, was a generous supporter of the Wesleyan Missionary Society, and who, by his munificence, has enabled us to erect this building.'', 'last_edit_date': '1896-03-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_03_1896#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.665, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Emigration Movement among the Africans in America', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'One of the remarkable movements of the day is the growing desire on the part of the freedmen of the South to emigrate to Liberia. Two thousand names are now on the rolls of the American Colonization Society, and these the names of the very best and most industrious of the coloured men of the South, who ask the society to send them to the land of their fathers. Some have petitioned Congress to send them over the sea, and some are striving to gather together sufficient funds to transport themselves and their families to Africa. Every week swells the number of those who want to go, and who would be accessions of value to the population of Liberia. And we must expect this movement to take larger proportions continually, just as the emigration from European lands to our own has swollen in the course of the last thirty years. Whether we think it wise in the black men to leave this country or not, we must expect to see every year increasing numbers depart, and a tide of emigration set eastward, not as large, but just as constant as the great tide which runs westward with such wonderful volume and force.—American Presbyterian.', 'last_edit_date': '1868-10-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1868#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.675, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Livingstone Congo Inland Mission', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The present moment, marking as it does an important era in the history of this Mission, occasioned by the transfer of its management from the hands of its founders—the East London Institute—to those of the American Baptist Missionary Union, is opportune for calling attention, even in the columns of a commercial journal, to the character of the work it has and is so nobly carrying on in the centre of Africa.', 'last_edit_date': '1884-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1884#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.656, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Laying the Foundation-stone of Palm Church, Lagos', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Thus we made the preliminary endeavours towards the noble work whose further expansion we are here met to commemorate. Let me, therefore, ask all of you here present to join with me to render our heartfelt thanks to Almighty God for His mercies in permitting us to be humble instruments in His hands to carry on this work—a work which leads me to think of the time when the foundation of the second temple was laid in Jerusalem, when the priests in their apparel with trumpets, and the Levites, the sons of Asaph, with cymbals praised the Lord by course, and gave thanks unto Him because He is good and His mercy endureth for ever towards Israel. Therefore, let us, like them, shout with a great shout while praising the Lord for His goodness, and His mercy enduring for ever towards us, because of this foundation of the house of God at Aroloya, which is now laid.

To-day we recall to mind fifty years ago, when Satan reigned supreme in this island of Lagos; when there was nothing but oppression, superstition, bloodshed, and robbery; when, in fact, Lagos was but a depôt for the inhuman traffic, the slave trade; and, as such, was diligently used by both European and other slave-buyers on the coast and natives in the interior countries, who gave themselves up for such work. But, through the instrumentality and missionary labours of the Church Missionary Society, which was commenced subsequently—viz., thirty-eight years ago, this stronghold of Satan has been successfully attacked from time to time by the preaching of God's word, which is the sword of the Spirit, and the result, as we see to-day, represents thousands that have been turned from darkness unto light, and from the power of Satan unto God. Well may we exclaim, "What hath God wrought?"

The Native Pastorate Church inherit the building of churches to the glory of God through its parent the Church Missionary Society, from St. Augustine and others who, about 1,300 years ago, established Native Churches in England, Germany, and other places. And what a great responsibility rests upon us Africans to carry on and consolidate the glorious work that we have received freely from our said parent, the Church Missionary Society.', 'last_edit_date': '1889-02-28', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/06_05_1889#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.666, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE CHRISTIAN CIVILIZATION OF AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Among the visible means for the accomplishment of the great work of the Christian civilization of Africa, we have ever pointed to a possible immigration into Africa of considerable numbers of American negroes released from the cruel yoke of slavery. Some people, with more energy than discretion, have from time to time carped at this, and made it a matter for accusation against us that we should hold such a doctrine. According to them, the only civilization for which those children of African blood could have been preparing in slavery, was the civilization of, and civilization in, the United States of America. According to them, the emancipated mass starts forth a species of moral phœnix from the ashes of an immoral servitude—they are admirably fitted for an immediate assimilation of blood with the other citizens of the Republic of European origin or descent—admirably fitted for all the duties of citizenship in the great American Republic; but it can never have been intended by God that the regeneration of Africa should in any way be owing to a preparation of the agents employed, under such a system of slavery as that which has been happily exterminated in the United States. They would have that great mass of people absorbed by the greater mass, by miscegenation or some other similar process—lost as a race by admixture with that mass—and that horrible system of which they were the suffering victims stand out for ever in the history of the past an enormity out of which no good has, no good ever could be evoked.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-11-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1865#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.666, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Emigration from the United States to Liberia', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The emigration during 1880 has been—by the barques Liberia, May 22; sixty persons; the Monrovia, May 29, seventy-six persons; the Liberia, November 1, six persons; and by the Tuck Sing, November 22, one person; making a total of one hundred and forty-three persons, exceeding in numbers those sent in any one year since 1872.

These emigrants were mostly in families, and removed from the following named places: New York City, 1; New Berne, 7; and Concord, N.C., 5; Nashville, Tenn., 1; De View, 10; and Phillips County, Arkansas, 108; and from Marshall, Texas, 11. Fortysix were reported as communicants in Evangelical churches. Of the adult males, 26 are farmers, 2 coopers, 1 blacksmith, 1 brickmaker, 2 school teachers, and 3 ordained ministers of the Gospel. Several families went to join relatives and acquaintances, who had written for them to come. All reached the vessels named at their own expense, and they also contributed $1,218.75 towards the cost of passage from New York. They were thoroughly provided for at sea and during the first six months after arrival at Brewerville, where they chose to settle. But four deaths were reported up to December 2nd, the date of our latest advices—viz., one female adult, from causes not peculiar to any climate, and three children. Of the latter, "one was a little girl who had pneumonia in New York, and was left with spinal disease; a boy who died of mumps coming back on him, and another from injuries received at school in the United States."—*African Repository.*', 'last_edit_date': '1881-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1881#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.664, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Relation between the Mohammedan Tribes of Africa and the Christians', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Professor Blyden (interviewed in the United States), says the *African Repository*, when asked "What is the relation between the native Mohammedan tribes of Africa and the Christians?" replied: "Christianity has not had a fair chance in Africa. In the first place, missionary operations have been confined to the unhealthy districts adjacent to the seaboard, and under such circumstances the efforts of the missionaries have been irregular. Men cannot do justice to their work when they are continually sailing. Again, the natives among whom the missionaries have laboured have also come into contact with European traders—Christians they claim to be—and practices have presented such a flagrant contrast to the teachings of the missionaries that what little good the latter have been able to accomplish in the face of the obstacles with which they have had to contend has been more than counterbalanced by the mischief wrought by the former. The children who attend the missionary schools are, as a rule, the children of the lower class of natives, and their home influences are not of a character favourable to the growth of Christian precepts. The Mohammedans on the other hand, coming from the east and north, belong to what you may call a cognate race to the negro. They are already acclimatized; they settle in negro towns, intermarry with the people and entirely amalgamate with them. By this means they come in contact with a better class of people and their influence is regular and continuous. The Arab traders do not bring with them the demoralizing commodities which form a large part of the stock in trade of the European traders. Hence travellers in Africa along the coast find that the negroes who are Mohammedans give greater evidence of self-respect and self-reliance than do most of those negroes who are Christians. It is a very serious and by no means agreeable contrast for the Christian world to contemplate. The Mohammedans everywhere strenuously oppose the introduction of ardent spirits into the country. If it were not for them, intoxicating liquors would have wrought fearful havoc among the native tribes." We regret that Mr. Blyden kept out of sight the demoralizing influences of Mohammedanism which have been so fatal in many parts of Africa. Mohammedan civilization! where it prevails, may be a seeming blessing to a few, but is a scourge and a degradation for the many; and in view of the horrible slave trade carried on by Mohammedans in Africa, we cannot imagine an enlightened African looking upon Mohammedanism as anything short of a curse to Africa.—Ed. *A.T.*', 'last_edit_date': '1882-11-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1882#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.663, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}]

hh: David Livingstone's explorations and death exemplify the deep European interest in African exploration and the complex interactions between European explorers and African communities, as evidenced by the support from both European and African individuals and institutions.
result: The observations from the "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles collectively support the claim that David Livingstone's explorations and death exemplify the deep European interest in African exploration and the complex interactions between European explorers and African communities. The textbook highlights Livingstone's travels in East and Central Africa, which inspired European missionary societies and explorers, and underscores the involvement of European institutions like the Church Missionary Society and the Universities Mission to Central Africa. It also notes the collaboration between African leaders and European powers, while acknowledging the often exploitative nature of these interactions. The African Times articles further emphasize the financial and institutional support Livingstone received from European entities such as the Royal Geographical Society and the Foreign Office, illustrating the European interest in African exploration. They also highlight the crucial role of Livingstone's African followers in preserving his body and ensuring its return to England, indicating cooperation between European explorers and African communities. However, the articles focus more on European support and the actions of individual Africans, without detailing African institutional support, thus highlighting a difference in emphasis between the two sources. Together, these observations illustrate the significant influence of Livingstone's explorations on European engagement in Africa and the multifaceted interactions between Europeans and Africans.

Never before did the crops look so green, advanced, and promising in March and April. All this is owing to a steady succession of genial rainfalls. The crop of Sugar is expected to be very large. This is very important for the colony, because Natal sugar has now become a favourite in the Australian markets. Coffee, Cotton, and all other products, look most promising, and a generally good yield is anticipated. Cotton, Flax, and other textile fabrics, are occupying attention in the colony. The average yield of Sea Island cotton will, it is said, be about 400lbs. of ginned cotton per acre. It is also now affirmed that cotton planting and sugar planting may be carried on successfully together, because at the time when labour is most wanted in the cotton fields it is least needed in the cane fields. Several patches of cotton, of a few acres each, are to be seen this year. But unless the Kafirs take to labour in the cotton fields, the labour question will be the great difficulty. The Flax that has been experimentally grown has given abundant yield, and the quality is reported as "very good." Wool is to become the favourite product of the upper country. There are continual importations of Sheep from the Cape, and of Rams of good breed from Australia and England. Some Alpacas are also expected from Australia. It is thought they are peculiarly suited to the hill pastures of Natal, and will give value to some of the wild kloofs of the country. Coffee planting is making steady progress. Coffee pays remarkably well, and its cultivation is therefore certain to be increased.

The Colonial-office in Downing-street has disallowed the bill passed last session for raising the Governor's salary from 1,200l. to 3,000l. a-year.

**Zambesi.**—An expedition on an extensive scale has left the Natal borders for the Zambesi. Waggons had been built specially for the purpose. The object is said to be sport. Other similar expeditions are likely to follow. The eldest son of Dr. Livingstone had arrived at Natal, from Glasgow, en route, to join his father at Quillimane.

**Gold.**—Some Australian and Californian gold-diggers have been exploring the quartz districts. Indications of gold were found; but their labours were not rewarded by the discovery of any nuggets.

**Kafir Wealth.**—At a grand Kafir wedding, the bride-cake cost 10l.'}, {'id': 551, 'article_title': 'EASTERN AFRICA', 'full_section_title': 'EASTERN AFRICA', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1865#article-20', 'issue_date': '23_02_1865', 'content': "Dr. Livingstone's proposed expedition to the district between the north of Lake Nyassa and the south of Lake Tanganyika assumes a substantial form. The Royal Geographical Society have held out the prospect of 500l., the Foreign-office are understood to promise a similar sum, and a private friend and admirer of Dr. Livingstone's has given anonymously 1,000l. In addition to all this, it appears that Dr. Livingstone's position as consul to the native races of Eastern Africa, with a salary of 500l. a-year, remains unmodified; though his duties as consul at Quillimane have ceased. Adequate funds are therefore in existence for the maintenance of the expedition, conducted, as it is proposed to be, in a simple and economical manner."}, {'id': 2740, 'article_title': 'Details of the Death of Dr. Livingstone', 'full_section_title': 'Details of the Death of Dr. Livingstone', 'last_edit_date': '04-30-1874', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/30_04_1874#article-27', 'issue_date': '30_04_1874', 'content': 'SUEZ, SUNDAY, March 29.—The Malwa arrived at Suez at eleven on Saturday night, having Mr. Arthur Laing and Jacob Wainwright on board, with the body of Livingstone. He had been ill with chronic dysentery for several months past. Although well supplied with stores and medicine, he seems to have had a presentiment that the attack would prove fatal. He rode a donkey, but was subsequently carried, and thus arrived at Muilala, beyond Lake Bemba, in Bisa country, where he said, "Build me a hut to die in." The hut was built by his followers, who first made him a bed. He suffered greatly, groaning night and day. On the third day he said, "I am very cold; put more grass over the hut." His followers did not speak or go near him. Kitumbo, Chief of Bisa, sent flour and beans, and behaved well to the party. On the fourth day Livingstone became insensible, and died about midnight. Majuhara, his servant, was present. His last entry in diary was on April 27. He spoke much and sadly of home and family. When first seized he told his followers he intended to exchange everything for ivory, to give to them, and to push on to Ujiji and Zanzibar, and try to reach England. On the day of his death the followers consulted what to do. The Nassick boys determined to preserve the remains. They were afraid to inform the chief of Livingstone's death. The secretary removed the body to another hut, around which he built a high fence to insure privacy. They opened the body and removed the internals, which were placed in a tin box and burned inside the fence under a large tree. Jacob Wainwright cut an inscription on the tree as follows: "Dr. Livingstone died on May 4, 1873," and superscribed the name of the head man, Susa. The body was preserved in salt, and dried in the sun for twelve days. Kitumbo was then informed of the death, and beat drums and fired guns as a token of respect, and allowed the followers to remove the body, which was placed in a coffin formed of bark, then journeyed to Unyanyembe about six months, sending an advance party with information addressed to Livingstone's son, which met Cameron. The latter sent back a bale of cloth and powder. The body arrived at Unyanyembe ten days after advance party, and rested there a fortnight. Cameron, Murphy, and Dillon together there. Latter very ill, blind, and mind affected. Committed suicide at Kssakera: buried there. Here Livingstone's remains were put in another bark case, smaller, done up as a bale to deceive natives who objected to the passage of the corpse, which was thus carried to Zanzibar. Livingstone's clothing, papers, and instruments accompany the body. When ill Livingstone prayed much. At Muilala he said, "I am going home." Chumah remains at Zanzibar. Webb, American consul at Zanzibar, is on his way home, and has letters handed to him by Murphy from Livingstone for Stanley, which he will deliver personally only. Geographical news follows. After Stanley's departure the Doctor left Unyanyembe, rounded the south end of Lake Tanganyika, and travelled south of Lake Bemba, or Bangweolo, crossed it south to north, then along east side, returning north through marshes to Muilala. All papers sealed.'}, {'id': 6162, 'article_title': 'MR. JOSEPH THOMSON.', 'full_section_title': 'MR. JOSEPH THOMSON.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_11_1891#article-6', 'issue_date': '02_11_1891', 'content': "Mr. Joseph Thomson arrived in London on Oct. 18 from South Africa. He left England about eighteen months ago to undertake an expedition on behalf of the British South Africa Company. After he reached the Shire certain modifications were made in his original plans. Accompanied by Mr. Grant, a son of Colonel Grant, Mr. Thomson made his way across the plateau between Lake Nyassa and Lake Bangweolo. He succeeded in making treaties with numerous chiefs, especially round the Bangweolo region, in favour of the Company. Of the agricultural value of the bulk of the plateau Mr. Thomson has formed a high estimate. Not only on the Blantyre highlands and on the heights around Lake Nyassa, but over the whole of the plateau he is convinced that, with reasonable care, Englishman could live and thrive as they do in India, for years together; but white colonisation, in the proper sense of the term, he does not believe possible, at least, under present circumstances. Mr. Thomson has been able to make important rectifications in the geography of the Bangweolo region. The lake, as shown in our maps, is incorrectly laid down, mainly because the one definite and precise observation taken by Livingstone has not been adhered to. The lake is really only a backwater of the Chambeze (the source of the Congo), which enters from the east, and issues from the west of the lake as the Luapula. It, in fact, lies in a very slight depression of the plateau, to the north of the Chambeze-Luapula. Even in the rainy season Mr. Thomson believes the lake does not exceed 20 ft. at its deepest. The southern shores are clothed with forests, and, as a matter of fact, his party encamped far within the bed of the lake as it is laid down in most maps. In the rainy season the water of the lake spreads out and covers for some distance the ground on which the forest stands. Mr. Thomson saw the tree on which Livingstone's men carved the record of the great traveller's death. He also spoke with two or three people who remember the white man's visit and death, and the tradition of it is well known among the populations around the lake."}]
