While religion necessarily remained the medium of expression of African aspirations, the concrete actions taken included labour unrest and refusal to pay taxes. Like the movements founded by Kimbangu and Mpadi, Ruben Spartas Mukasa in Uganda founded the African Progressive Association, and the Christian Army for the Salvation of Africa. An ex-serviceman in the King's African Rifles, Mukasa gave expression to the unifying purpose of all these movements when he promised to work for the redemption of Africa at whatever personal risks. When he started a branch of the African Orthodox Church in Uganda, the political and social purpose was clear in his declaration that the Church was '... for all right-thinking Africans, men who wish to be free in their own house, not always being thought of as boys'. Mukasa's church spread to Kenya. Of the same stamp was Jordan Msuma's Last Church of God and His Christ in Nyasaland as were the various African and Aladura churches in West Africa.
Islam represented a counterpoise to colonial ideology as well as a forum for the expression of messianism. The Mahdï is for the Muslim as the Messiah is for the Christian. Mahdism haunted colonial authorities in North and West Africa, in the Sudan and Somaliland. The Sanüsiyya in Italian-dominated Libya, as we have seen already, presented perhaps the clearest example of the expression of African nationalism and anticolonialism through Islam. Pan-Islamism, the religious side of the culturebound pan-Arabism and the idea of the Salafiya, also played a prominent role in the nationalist and colonial politics in Egypt, the Maghrib and northern Anglo-Egyptian Sudan. The Sanüsiyya influence as an anticolonial force spread to parts of West Africa. The colonial authorities found Islamic movements like the Hamalliyya, the Tijaniyya, and Mouridiyya a constant threat to the security of the colonial system.
These Islamic movements provided a strong link among adherents who found themselves under different colonial regimes. From the First World War on, as Crowder has shown above,$^{17}$ pan-Islamic ideology being disseminated from Turkey was a worrying issue to colonial authorities in many parts of Africa. It was a problem colonial rulers sought to tackle through the exchange of information and inter-colonial co-operation.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.645, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Africa at the beginning of the nineteenth century: issues and prospects', 'section_title': 'Internal initiatives', 'content': 'This groping for renewal and reform is just as discernible in the activities of various rulers who faced the challenges of the Mfecane, of those seeking to re-establish imperial order in Ethiopia, or those of the shaykhs of the Western and Central Sudan looking to the traditions of Islam for ideas of a new social and political order. Largely because of the writings of the djihad leaders and European travellers, we know enough about the complex of forces and ideas that produced the series of revolutionary movements starting from Futa Toro, Futa Jallon and Bondu in the eighteenth century and stretching to the Sokoto, Massina and Dinguiraye djihäds in the nineteenth. We therefore do not need to speculate about the possible contribution to that complex of forces and ideas of European mercantilist influence in the days of the slave trade or capitalist influence in the days of abolition and journeys of discovery. The initiative for the djihäd movements came from within. The djihäd states took a great interest in promoting agriculture, partly through traditional household production, partly also through estates worked by slave or client labour. They also promoted industrial manufacture and trade. They improved trade routes and offered protection to traders and merchants. By far the greatest portion of the traffic on the routes was for local and regional exchange. But the djihad leaders also promoted trans-Saharan trade routes and the pilgrimage route to the Eastern Sudan, the Nile Valley and Mecca. Evidence is building up that these internal trading initiatives had developed trade routes that permitted trans-continental traffic before the new European trade of the nineteenth century.$^{28}$ The Europeans, of course, were quick to note the results of these internal initiatives and were attracted to the possibility of profiting from them.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.642, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'African initiatives and resistance in the face of partition and conquest', 'section_title': 'The generality of resistance', 'content': "It is clear also that the old attempts to distinguish naturally warlike from naturally peaceful African societies are beside the point. I have argued myself in a number of articles that so far as large-scale African polities are concerned it makes no sense to discriminate between so-called warlike, raiding states, and so-called peaceful, trading and cultivating ones, since virtually all states made some attempt to find a basis on which to manipulate the Europeans without recourse to arms; virtually all of them had some crucial interests or values which they were prepared to defend, if necessary by armed resistance.$^{3}$ But I was myself mistaken to go on to argue that the foremost among the societies engaged in either resistance or manipu› lation had more in common with each other 'than with those small-scale societies that could neither resist nor exploit colonial rule'.$^{4}$ Among others, Shula Marks has shown in her study of Khoisan resistance in South Africa that non-centralized peoples are just as capable of putting up a determined fight against white advance as centralized ones. John Thornton has con› trasted the resistance potential of states and of stateless societies much to the advantage of the latter: States are often praised for their role in resistance to the European invasion ... actually ... their role was ambiguous. Some, it is true, resisted fairly well ... But many other state societies collapsed on impact with the Europeans ... On the other hand the resistance of stateless societies was often long-lived and heroic... it was the stateless societies - Igbo, Baule, Agni and others - that carried on the guerrilla wars. 5", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.629, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}]
tat_orig: [{'id': 520, 'article_title': 'AFRICAN SUBSCRIPTIONS TO THE AFRICAN-AID SOCIETY', 'full_section_title': 'AFRICAN SUBSCRIPTIONS TO THE AFRICAN-AID SOCIETY', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1865#article-11', 'issue_date': '23_01_1865', 'content': "In our closing number for 1864 we stated the necessity of increased funds, if the Society is to fight the battle of African civilization before the committee of the House of Commons during the coming session of Parliament. It has been a cause of great satisfaction to us to receive the above donations from M'Carthy's Island; and these, too, spontaneously collected by Dr. Horton before our remarks of last month had reached the Gambia. It is an encouraging fact that, with one or two exceptions, such as the Commandant, &c., all the contributors are Africans. We cannot too strongly urge upon the Africans in every part of West Africa to which this journal penetrates, that all our efforts are directed to procuring for them increased facilities and protection—for advancing their interests and the Christian civilization of their native countries. Doctor Horton suggests in his letter that the Africans on the Coast ought to contribute the 200l. a-year which the Society requires in order to give it sufficient freedom of action. If all the native traders down the Coast would make it a personal affair; if every one would for himself determine to be an annual subscriber of, say, only one guinea to the Society, and to send this subscription forward regularly, we should indeed feel stimulated anew, and powerfully stimulated, to increased exertions for them. It will be a proud day for us when we can say to the English friends of Africa, as well as to the revilers of Africa, that the African-Aid Society has an African list of subscribers, whose annual contributions render it independent of lukewarm European sympathies. Such a position would greatly strengthen our hands, both with the British Government and the British public. It will do much for us to be able to show them an educated Africa, keenly alive to its responsibilities towards those from among whom they have been brought out by the education they have received—fully alive to the necessity of those ameliorations of Government system, and those increased facilities for the development of African resources, for which we, in their interest, have ever been contending. We write freely, because we do not want one penny of their money for ourselves—but only for those disbursements necessarily attendant on public action. All we do for them is done gratuitously, in the hope of advancing God's cause in the world—and all we ask from them in return is to evince their sense of the importance and utility of our services—of those services which have really now given to West Africa a voice and a representation in Europe—by relieving us from the painful necessity of having to ask from others the small amount necessary to cover the unavoidable expenses incurred in thus serving them. If some leading native trader at each trading station, or town, or river along the West Coast, would organise the work among his fellow-traders, all that is wanted might speedily be accomplished."}, {'id': 4783, 'article_title': 'THE INTERNATIONAL AFRICAN ASSOCIATION.', 'full_section_title': 'THE INTERNATIONAL AFRICAN ASSOCIATION.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1884#article-5', 'issue_date': '01_02_1884', 'content': 'Sir,—The leading article on the work of the International African Association in Western Africa, and the notice of my recent mission to the Congo, in the *Times* of this morning, embolden me to ask the insertion of a few more words on the same subject. The objects of the Association have been so strangely misconstrued, and its acts so palpably misrepresented, by writers in the British as well as Continental Press, that contradiction on certain heads appears imperative. I select two of the more important charges. First, "It seems rather difficult to understand," we are told, "how the natives can be civilized, or commerce introduced, at the point of the bayonet." Now no single station of the Association can be said to have been established by force. The means used have been purely pacific; and if at any time collision has occurred with natives, the occurrence must be held as exceptional, of a local character, and in no way affecting the general principles of action. Secondly, objection has been urged to the stringency of particular treaties made with the native chiefs, because the terms used lead to the belief that territory acquired by the Association will be considered ground on which to levy tolls and customs, and generally impede free trade. In reality, the Association has no intention whatever to enclose its free stations with any line of "douane." On the contrary, it is ready to pledge itself, to all Governments requiring the pledge, to do nothing of the kind, as well as to grant any *bonâ fide* trader the same privileges and rights which are enjoyed by the occupants of its stations and free territory. The work is one of philanthropy, and those who have hitherto supplied and continue to supply funds for its performance are thoroughly conscious that they are not creating for themselves any sources of income. They trust that civilization and commerce will follow their footsteps; and should such indeed be the result, they will consider themselves amply repaid for any sacrifice they may have made. I will not now take up your space by referring to other accusations, except the statement that "duels were not infrequent" among the *employés* at the Congo. I am not aware of one. There are, however, two or three trifling points in your notice of my mission to which I would ask permission to allude, to prevent misconception. On going up the river on the 6th of September, I only proceeded by steamer as far as Noki. Thence to Vivi there remain some 15 rough miles to be accomplished by land or in small craft. I first went the former way, though I returned by water, and subsequently ran up to Vivi from Banana, and returned in the little tender, Belgique. Banana is hardly a "station" for the Association, which has no *pied-a-terre* on the actual coast; and the import of Madras and other Indian goods applies rather to the coast trade than to the Congo River. —I remain, Sir, yours obediently,\n\nF. J. Goldsmid.'}]

[{'document_title': 'MR. JOSEPH THOMSON ON EUROPEAN INTERCOURSE WITH AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Mr. Joseph Thomson, the African explorer, lectured at Edinburgh, on January 11, on "The result to the African of European intercourse." There was a large attendance.

The Lecturer, after observing that one of the most remarkable features of the century had been the phenomenal interest displayed in all things African, and that people's imaginations had been touched by the varied story of the Dark Continent, drew attention to the apparently unselfish form of the public interest manifested in Africa. The very atmosphere was electric with the most wonderful schemes—religious, philanthropic, and commercial—for the exclusive benefit of the negro. From platform and pulpit rose a clamour of voices, in which was heard the popular watchwords of the day—civilisation, progress, the good of the negro, legitimate commerce, conversion of the heathen, and other high-sounding phrases, all having relation to the good things to be done for the African. The company-promoter freely sprinkled his prospectuses or his conversation with glowing accounts of the great benefits which the African was to derive from intercourse with Europe. They were told to picture as the result the negro clothed and in his right mind, alternately sitting at the feet of the missionary and the trader, learning from the one the truths of a higher and better life, and from the other acquiring the arts of civilisation. They never heard now of the trader who went to Africa with the merely selfish object of making his fortune. Each and all became pioneers of civilisation, thinking only of the native first and self afterwards. They spoke as if the good to the native had been enormous, and that their intercourse with him had been a benefit and blessing. They pointed with pride to their sacrifices in the suppression of the slave trade, to their West Coast settlements as centres of secular light and leading; to their missionary stations as stars twinkling in the night of heathendom; to the returns of their trade with every entrance to the heart of Africa, as showing the spread of their beneficial influence. They saw that the work of other nations had been pernicious in the extreme, that they had been brutal in their dealings with native races, and had thought only of their own sordid interests and national aggrandisement—all in marked contrast to their aims and methods.', 'last_edit_date': '1890-01-11', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1890#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.676, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Tribute to the African-Aid Society', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'WE have been often rather tauntingly asked what the African-Aid Society is really effecting. Because querists could not see in our columns that the Society had sent "—emigrants to Africa on board the ship —," &c., they refused to comprehend that a great work was advancing under our hands. They forgot that one of our great objects is to prepare Africa for that influx of colonial civilization which will one day come in to accelerate her progress, as well as to help to bring in that coloured civilization to a home and a mission in Africa.

Under these circumstances, the letter from Anamaboe, which we now publish, is doubly gratifying to us. We offer our grateful thanks to our Gold Coast and other African friends for that and other evidences which we are now receiving of their appreciation of the benefits we are conferring upon Africa. We know that, if only adequately supported, we shall, within the next few years, be able, by God's help and blessing, to produce results in

**NOVEMBER 23, 1863.**

Africa that half a century, without the African-Aid Society or a similar organization, would not have witnessed.

The following is the letter above referred to:—

**TO THE PRESIDENT AND MEMBERS OF THE AFRICAN-AID SOCIETY,  
8, ADELPHI-TERRACE, LONDON.**

Anamaboe, Gold Coast.

Gentlemen,—The immense good which the African-Aid Society has done for the Coast of Africa since their formation is a thing that is universally acknowledged by every African on the Coast. Through it the poorest man here has a means by which his grievances can be made known, and the want of the whole country properly represented in influential quarters; and I am sure that by the effectual organization of the African-Aid Society many valuable measures which have been proposed to the Government, having for object the raising of Africa from its degradation, but which have been squashed by Europeans on the Coast, who are dead against every measure having such tendency, will soon be so represented, that the Government will not hesitate to carry them into effect.

I am unable to express to you how grateful we are for what you have hitherto done; your Society is a necessity to Africa—a vital and indispensable one—and your existence will always ensure real, deep, and important improvements in Africa.

Truly satisfied of the inestimable benefit we have derived from the African-Aid Society and its valuable paper, I have endeavoured to urge their support not only amongst my countrymen, but also amongst Europeans, and request them to subscribe liberally to both; and I have improved the opportunity I lately had of visiting Cape Coast by calling upon each gentleman and asking his support. I am happy to state that they gave liberally towards my appeal. The only unfortunate circumstance is that the war has destroyed the country, and there is no trade whatever, or I might have been able to forward you more. I hope you will acknowledge the subscriptions in the African Times.', 'last_edit_date': '1863-11-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1863#article-19', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.674, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African-Aid Society and the Missionary Societies', 'section_title': '', 'content': "We alluded last month to the intimate connexion which must necessarily exist between the work of the African-Aid Society and that of the various missionary societies which are striving for the introduction and spread of Christianity in native Africa. There are two great objects kept constantly in view in the operations of our society—the increase of a civilising and humanising commerce, and the displacement of pagan superstitions, with all their frightful adjuncts of horrors, by that Christianity without which no true elevation and real civilization is possible to any people. So far as we ourselves are personally concerned, we do not for a moment hesitate to say that in all our efforts, the spread of the Redeemer's kingdom upon earth is the great object for which we labour, and that we regard the commercial adjuncts only as secondary, though, in our opinion, indispensable to the rapid progress of Gospel truth among the debased populations of Africa.", 'last_edit_date': '1864-11-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1864#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.708, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African-Aid Society and the Missionary Societies', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'that has deepened and intensified the horrors of an enormity, barbarism, and bloody superstition which so pre-eminently characterise Africa?

Without at present particularising our efforts in other parts of Africa, let us instance those we have been and are making for obtaining roads on the Gold Coast, and especially from the seacoast to the Ashantee frontier. Why are we urging this upon the Government—upon governors, and upon subjects? Because with an increase of the useful power of civilised government in the interior, those roads will also act as a curb to the aggressive instincts of Ashantee—as stimulants to increased production, because affording facilities for increased commerce—as placing the engines of civilization in immediate contact with the hitherto unmitigated barbarous superstitions of Ashantee; and rendering it possible for the missionary society labouring in the protectorate to advance and maintain its outposts, in an efficient state at a considerable distance from the Coast without a ruinous expense, and without that dangerous and weakening isolation which has hitherto almost neutralised the zeal and devotion of its indefatigable agents.

In such a country as Africa, and among such people as the Africans, the power of Christian civilization must be exhibited wherever there are efforts for inculcating Christianity, if these latter are to have any corresponding success. The creation and maintenance of good roads, where such facilities for intercommunication have hitherto been unknown, would be a great and useful exhibition of the power of Christian civilization. They could not fail surely and more or less rapidly to ameliorate the social condition of a people which, amid tropical luxuriance, suffers most frightful privations. And every stage of that amelioration would be a material argument that all could appreciate in favour of that Christianity which the missionary would be engaged in teaching. Such palpable evidences that Christianity has the "promise of the life that now is" will dispose them the more readily to believe that it has also indeed and in truth "the promise of that which is to come." And in our humble opinion it is as much the duty of a Christian people to exhibit such material evidences to the heathen, as adjuncts to missionary teaching, as it is their duty to send the latter. The material blessings which God has bestowed upon the world through Christianity ought to be pressed into his service as allies of Gospel truth. These can exercise an influence upon the yet unconverted heathen, and predispose him to listen to those who may be striving for his eternal welfare, although of themselves they are, of course, without any regenerating power; and may even, when unaccompanied by Christianity, only add new vices to the old degradation.', 'last_edit_date': '1864-11-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1864#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.676, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'An Appeal from the Religious Society of Friends on Behalf of Uncivilized Nations', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We desire to call the attention of our own members, and of our fellow-Christians generally, to our solemn responsibility as a nation for the treatment of the uncivilized tribes with whom we are brought into contact by the great increase of commerce and the steady progress of geographical discovery.

We do not wish hastily to judge how far our fellow-countrymen have been justified in a course of action towards them which has so often led to painful collision, and even to bloodshed. We know that, whether from conflicting interests or from mutual suspicion and misunderstanding, the position of those who are brought into contact with the savage is one of great practical difficulty. His character is often a degraded one, treacherous and bloodthirsty.

Yet he is man, formed in the image of his and our Maker,—an object, with ourselves, of the sacrifice of the Son of God, and of the promises of the Gospel.

How grave is the responsibility resting upon us as a nation in reference to our conduct towards him! How needful it is that we should be guided, in our intercourse with him, by the precepts of that holy religion which we profess! How important that, in using the superior powers which civilization has given us, we should carefully restrain and keep under any feeling of revenge!

We have thankfulness and satisfaction in observing how earnestly desirous our nation seems to be to be quite clear of the sin of "man-stealing." May we also keep before us the responsibility which our wide-spread empire involves, and make every endeavour to preserve towards the uncivilized and the heathen a line of conduct consistent with our Christian profession!

It is in the love of Christ that we make this appeal. We trust that, under the Divine blessing, it will meet with a response in the hearts of many who, amidst the stir and pleasure of active life, dare not disclaim either the hopes or responsibilities of the Christian. The precepts of Christ are not mere theories, but commands graciously designed and fitted for man. They are therefore to be implicitly obeyed, in their comprehensive application to his whole conduct towards his fellow-man, civil, commercial and social. The uncivilized often appreciate Christian conduct even when they have but little knowledge of the truths upon which it is founded. The heart that is steeled by oppression may be melted by kindness. Love will often prevail where fraud and deceit would only provoke irritation and conflict.

Let the religion of the Christian trader be never disgraced by acts of injustice or revenge. Let him commend it to the consciences of men, of every colour and of every clime, by fair dealing, by truth-speaking, by compassion and love, patience and forbearance. Thus might our commerce, far more than it does, reflect our Christian profession, and so far prepare the way for the reception of the Gospel amongst those who have not yet been brought under its influences.', 'last_edit_date': '1876-05-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1876#article-25', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.669, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': '1863 AND 1864, AND THE AFRICAN-AID SOCIETY.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'filthiness, she glories in her vileness, and feels no need of renovation. Good must be forced upon her. She must be won, if possible, through material benefits to a moral change. The life of civilization must be brought to bear upon the torpor of barbarism. Africa must be roused to industrial vigour and productive activity before high aspirations can take the place of vile and disgusting cravings. To organise and urge on the army of regeneration is the work in which we of the African-Aid Society are engaged. It is a comparatively slow and arduous work. The forces are so disproportioned, if only numerically contrasted; and we are not surprised that they who only thus contrast the forces and estimate the progress of the work, should feel discouragement. But if they will rise to the height of so great a mission, that discouragement will give place to noble and enthusiastic, to vigorous and patient effort. The infidel may sneer at the prophecy of "the sweet singer of Israel," and taunt us with the centuries that have passed away since he predicted that she should "soon" stretch out her hands unto God (although that "soon" was not soon after the delivery of the prophecy, but soon after certain events then also foretold). But they will feel with us, that time, in the eternal councils, is not measured by the standard of presumptuous human unbelief. The promise is sure. Good shall prevail over evil in Africa as elsewhere. How will the victory be achieved? Not without human agency. The workers of material regeneration must be with the van of the army. All the forces of Christian civilization must move on together. Civilised government, industrial development, employment of capital, commercial enterprise, scientific power, must march shoulder to shoulder with moral and spiritual teaching and example. Christianity is for this world as well as for the next; it ameliorates the present in its every condition and relation, while pointing to the perfect future. And the misguided individual who would set about renovating and civilising Africa without the life-bestowing aid of Christianity, might be as profitably engaged in making sandrope cables for the ships of Her Majesty's navy.', 'last_edit_date': '1863-12-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1863#article-14', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.666, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African-Aid Society and the Missionary Societies', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'No one, we think, who has attentively considered the subject of missionary effort in native Africa, can have remained blind to the fact of the great obstacles placed in the way of such noble efforts, by the total absence among the African populations of those facilities for action which the accessories of an extensive commerce and of civilised rule, present to the missionary in almost all other great fields of missionary labour in heathen lands. The African-Aid Society acts, therefore, as the pioneer of Christian missions, in its endeavours to remove those exceptional obstacles, which not only add very much to the expense of those missions, and to the privations and dangers of the devoted missionaries, but limit also the extension of those missions, and retard their great work of the proclamation of the glad tidings of salvation, the acceptance of which can alone remove the bleeding woes of Africa. We feel that the African-Aid Society cannot have a more glorious title than that of "THE PIONEER OF CHRISTIAN MISSIONS AND OF CIVILISING COMMERCE." It is in this capacity of pioneer that the efforts of the society have been so much directed toward the Gambia and the Sherboro countries, and toward our Gold Coast possessions, Dahomey, and the districts in which the great river Niger presents a path for missionary and commercial action. It is as a "pioneer" that it waits, and watches, and acts (so far as circumstances will permit) for the removal or modification of those deep curses to Eastern Africa, the Portuguese rule from Delagoa Bay to the territories of Zanzibar, and the connivance of the Sultan of the latter, for pecuniary considerations, at that devastating slave-trade carried on by the Arabs with the Persian Gulf. What a field of arduous labour is here presented to the Christian view—is here placed before the philanthropist, the statesman, and the merchant. And are we not justified in saying that it is a disgrace to a Christian and enlightened country and people—a country and a people whom God has specially entrusted with the work of the spread of the Gospel of Christ and of true civilization among the nations—that such a work should languish for want of a very moderate degree of encouragement and support? Few societies that effect any permanent good are grand in their beginnings. Precociousness in them, as in children, is fatal to real power. Fiction alone starts into complete existence; while the realities of life build up gradually the individual and general structures of human history. Error is glittering; nothing is easier than to dazzle and win with it. Truth is the reverse of this; and struggles amid difficulty and hardship into appreciation and favour. Look at our great missionary societies. Consult their early records. The Church Missionary Society was at first very coldly received. During some years its income fluctuated from three or four hundred to a thousand pounds a-year. People who could not, or did not, care to see, or were unable to grasp the great principle of its existence, sneered at it, no doubt. It was doing nothing, of course. No one could perceive any rich fruit of its exertions; and yet it had sown and gathered something in from the first seed—and yet it was from the first moment gradually advancing toward the great harvest of its present utility—and yet it had securely laid the foundation of its present goodly edifice. The germ of its actual vigorous life was swelling amid the cerements of the national apathy, anon to throw out its roots, to raise high its head and spread wide its branches; to fatten and flourish in the rich soil and sunshine of popular wealth and favour, and cast around the precious leaves of Christian truth appointed for the healing of the nations.

The day for this is slowly breaking; we who are watching can already perceive its light on the horizon. And when that day once fairly breaks, we believe the triumph of Christian civilization over African barbarism will be a rapid one. The facilities afforded by an enormous European wealth, and the discoveries and appliances of modern science and industry, are so great and varied, that when once the conviction gains, Africa can supply what the world wants, she can afford to pay the agents who wrest it from her stimulated energies, she must have civilization introduced within her, whether she desires it or not—when once, we say, this conviction gains the leading political and commercial minds of the age, then the progress of Africa will be rapid, because the selfishness of civilization embarked in the enterprise will be accompanied by Christian effort, and will be overruled by a directing Providence towards those blessed results which are pointed out on the glowing page of inspired prophesy. But that the climate of Africa placed serious obstacles in the way of European occupation, the tide of conquest by civilized nations would long ere this have swept over it from north to south and from east to west, claiming it and its vast and valuable natural productions and undeveloped wealth for the use and enjoyment of the great human family, which, under the impulse of progressive civilization, and to meet the necessities it is constantly creating, demands the beneficial utilization of every natural gift with which the Divine Creator has endowed this earth, and on which He placed it with the command that it should replenish and subdue it. The swarthy races in Africa have not done their part in this great work to which the Creator appointed mankind. It has yet to be accomplished, and the time seems now to be at hand for it to commence. The spirit of civilized progress now claiming Africa has put forth its claims with so much vigour, at so many points, and in so many diverse ways; the public attention and interest are invited and demanded so persistently and forcibly; the torpor of the African peoples if left to themselves, and their utter inability of themselves, or by the aid of mere trading or missionary effort, to make even the smallest advances towards civilization and Christianity, has become so incontestable,—that we look forward now confidently not only to a continuance of mercantile enterprise and the efforts of Christian philanthropy in its yearning for African souls, but to the speedy operation, also, of Governments and associations in furtherance of those claims. Yes, thanks be to God, we see such forces marshalling to assail the power of Satan, the evil enemy of mankind, in Africa and throughout Africa, that, although we cannot but deplore what seems to us the mistaken award of Marshal MacMahon as regards the right of sovereignty over Delagoa Bay—respecting which we shall have something to say in our next issue—we can rejoice, and we do rejoice, in spirit. Human interest, resting in Europe upon the strong fulcrum of human wants, is the mighty lever that God has clearly ordained for lifting the great continent of Africa to the position she has been endowed for. She has passed rapidly, though it may seem to have been slowly, through the earlier stages of her elevation. The epoch of more potent effort has now arrived. Combined mercantile energy enters the rich field where legitimate individual enterprise has been preparing the way for it. Just as powerful European organizations prosecuted the slave-trade in Africa which individual cupidity desultorily commenced, and thus gave to that accursed traffic the enormous development to which it attained, so will powerful European organizations now take the field in giving development to that legitimate commerce for which Africa possesses so many rich and copious elements. A century and a-half ago English African companies were erecting their fortified slave factories along the Western Coast of Africa. Now English African companies are holding out their peaceful hands to the African people, to tempt them onward in the path of agricultural industry. There are large fields for legitimate commercial action in Africa, and large profits to be obtained there, if they be honestly, actively, and intelligently sought by organizations of practical experienced men, with such sufficient capital as shall enable them to plant firmly where they trade, the standard of their peaceful industrial array. Companies with too restricted capital can only do the same sort of work that individual merchants have been and are performing. This was and is useful enough for Africa, and beneficial to the merchant, as far as it can prudently go. But Africa now wants more than this. She wants powerful companies, that shall prudently but boldly stimulate and assist her to a much higher and more extensive industrial development. The Company of African Merchants is, and is intended to be, such an one. That it will open to England the great national storehouses of African cotton, we have no doubt; while it will be at the same time be helping forward and reaping other portions of its harvests in the long-opened fields of oils, gums, and other such articles of African produce. hh: Philanthropic efforts in the late 19th century, exemplified by events like the 1866 African Bazaar, were organized to financially support educational and missionary initiatives in Africa.
result: The General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles provide complementary perspectives on philanthropic efforts in the late 19th century aimed at supporting educational and missionary initiatives in Africa. The General History of Africa emphasizes the significant contributions of Christian missions, colonial governments, and local African initiatives in establishing schools and promoting literacy, highlighting the involvement of Afro-Americans in missionary work. However, it does not specifically mention organized philanthropic events like the 1866 African Bazaar, which is a notable omission in relation to the claim. In contrast, The African Times articles provide detailed accounts of various fundraising activities, such as bazaars and concerts, organized to financially support educational and missionary projects. These articles highlight efforts by individuals like Mrs. Joseph Moseley, who organized a bazaar and concert to fund her mission in Cape Coast, and Mr. Edward S. Morris, who aimed to establish a college in Liberia. They also discuss the establishment of educational institutions like the Congo Institute at Colwyn Bay, supported by donations. While the articles do not specifically mention the 1866 African Bazaar, they offer a broader context of philanthropic activities during this period, aligning with the claim. Together, these sources illustrate the philanthropic focus on education and missionary work in Africa, despite the absence of direct references to specific events like the African Bazaar in the textbook.

[{'document_title': 'THE CONGO INSTITUTE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Yet another scheme is formulated for the divergence of a little of the money which is evidently forthcoming in this year of commemoration to a channel whose course runs in a direction that should arrest the attention of every English man and woman who has a spark of that Christianity so nobly set forth by the late Dr. Livingstone. The scheme is one for the establishment of an institute for the training of negro girls to be run on lines similar to those followed in the working of the Congo Institute at Colwyn Bay, where young men are educated, trained up in Gospel truths on unsectarian lines, and taught a trade, whereby they can earn their own living by craftsmanship, and impart in their native tongue the knowledge they possess to their benighted fellow countrymen instructing them not only in ethics, but useful trades. Mr. Hughes, the principal, wishes to extend the benefactions to girls, and for this purpose makes an appeal for funds, which it is hoped will be responded to in a manner worthy the cause, not only for the sake of the spiritual leaven, but in the interests of commerce, which such an effort induces and stimulates.

The scheme of education as carried out at the Colwyn Bay Institute has been found to work most satisfactorily. Among its chief advantages may be pointed out: (1) The boys are taken away from old and injurious surroundings, from old practices, superstitions, temptations, and evil influences; (2) They for four or five years are residents in a Christian country and under new and beneficial influence, and see the benefits of civilisation; (3) They acquire without difficulty the English language, and, indeed, are able to read and study English books and translate them into their native language; (4) The youths are educated to become thorough masters of some handicraft.

It should perhaps be mentioned that carpentering, printing, tailoring, &c., are taught them free, for the Welsh people have never charged a single apprenticeship fee; and Messrs. Elder, Dempster & Co., the great African shippers, convey the students to and from Africa free.

Most successfully has the scheme worked; the boys who have returned to Africa have all done well. They carry back with them tools and other appliances, which enable them to earn an honest living, and, at the same time, to impart instruction to others.', 'last_edit_date': '1897-04-05', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/05_04_1897#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.675, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'CHRISTIAN EDUCATION FOR AND IN AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In answer to an invitation from Samuel Gurney, Esq., to meet Mr. Edward S. Morris, of Philadelphia and Liberia, a meeting was held at Devonshire House, London, April 21st, 1879, when the following resolution was unanimously passed: "That the thanks of this meeting be given to Mr. Morris, for his interesting and encouraging statement on the condition and prospects of Liberia; that we fully agree with him as to the crying necessity for Christian schools in Africa, and earnestly desire that every necessary means may be given him to make his estate (800 acres) in Liberia a nursery of education, industrial as well as literary—especially for the sons of native chiefs, and the future kings of Africa." Mr. Morris was recommended to Samuel Gurney, Esq. by Mr. Welsh, the United States Minister in London, in terms which we feel compelled to quote: "Mr. Morris has thrown an enthusiastic energy into the work he has entered upon, which gives the strongest promise of success. His earnest desire is for the Christian education of the sons of the savage chiefs who border on Liberia. They are to be the future rulers of Africa. This is to be his life-work; and his instruments will be schools for the purpose established in Liberia. In such a cause he cannot fail to have the support of many good people." Mr. Morris has secured an estate of 800 acres in Liberia, where he is about to erect his college, in which he proposes to educate the sons of native kings and chiefs. His admirable plan is to make them at the same time educated men, Christians, and practical coffee planters and general agriculturists. This is surely a work fraught with well-grounded hopes of at present incalculable good to Africa; and as such, Mr. Morris, who seems to us to be peculiarly fitted for it, has our warmest desires and earnest prayers for a full measure of success. Mr. T. A. Denny, of London, has promised 100l. of the 1,000l. required by Mr. Morris, who, in his letter to Joseph Gurney Barclay, Esq., and George Williams, Esq.,—well-known in London business circles—who have accepted the office of Treasurers for the funds which Mr. Morris hopes to collect while in England, says: "When the school-house shall have been built, the teacher engaged and at his post of duty, and the boys in their seats, THEN will I commence to draw on the funds deposited, and placed in your hands as Treasurers."', 'last_edit_date': '1879-04-21', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1879#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.682, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE GAMBIA, WEST AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Appeal of a Native African Clergyman on behalf of his Fellow-Countrymen.

The Rev. George Nicol, Colonial Chaplain of the British Settlements of the River Gambia, who is at present on a visit to this country, desires to draw attention to the following statement: His special work is to minister to the officers of the Colonial Government, the European merchants, and the large and increasing body of Christian traders who are constantly coming into the settlement from Sierra Leone and other parts of the Coast. To these he ministers, and superintends an organization similar to that found in any well-worked parish in England. The congregation is occasionally increased by the visit of one of Her Majesty’s ships. He has also the spiritual charge of the convicts in the gaol and the inmates of the Colonial Hospital. In connection with the Colonial Church at Bathurst there is now a congregation of 200 Christian worshippers and about eighty communicants. The church can only accommodate 250. In addition to the work connected with his chaplaincy, Mr. Nicol recognizes the claims of the heathen upon the Christian Church, and has started three missions for those in and around the town of Bathurst; but as yet has been unable to reach the neighbouring tribes—namely, the Jolas, the Sérérés, the Polos, and the Mandingoes. For upwards of 600 miles higher up the River Gambia, on either bank of that noble river, one mercantile firm alone has seventy trading factories. There is not one resident missionary preaching the Gospel to the people trading with these merchants. Merchant clerks and other traders go up and down the country for the purpose of trade, but there is not one Christian teacher, European or native, who has taken up his residence among the people to learn their language and to instruct them. It is this sad state of things Mr. Nicol is anxious to remedy. He has formed at the Gambia a Native Church Missionary Association, and by the aid of his congregation and the merchants on the spot, has raised 50l. and built a small school chapel on the outskirts of Bathurst which is open daily for service and evangelistic meetings, and where a lay-helper is rendering efficient service. He has also been invited to build another chapel at Albreda, eighty miles up the river.

The present appeal is for funds to build School Chapels and Mission Houses at several of the most important trading stations. To do this satisfactorily, 1,000l. must be raised; and to maintain the necessary mission agents and teachers, at least 500l. per annum is required.

It may be added that the Church Missionary Society would rejoice to see this work advanced, though unable themselves to undertake the responsibility of any fresh expenditure in this part of the world; and that the Rev. R. C. Billing, who has for so many years been interested in the Native African Church and its missionary activities, has carefully considered these proposals with Mr. Nicol.', 'last_edit_date': '1883-01-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1883#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.672, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Mission Work in Africa, Africans Helping Themselves', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Rev. W. T. Pallen thus writes to the Wesleyan Committee (the Chapel has been undergoing repair.—*Ed. A. T.*) "I must tell you of a very interesting meeting held the other night in connection with our work. Our roof and ceiling were finished and the galleries entered upon, when I found that funds were getting low. I issued handbills on Saturday evening, calling a special meeting for Monday night, not stating for what it was called. Nobody knew about it, and curiosity was excited. The large schoolroom was filled with people, and after opening the meeting I at once told them if they wanted me to go on with the work, I must have more money. I should say that we had already collected over 200l. The people were anxious that the work should go on, of which they there and then gave practical proof. One man got up and said he would give two guineas; another, who had given me seven guineas before, gave 20l; another, who before, had given 6l. 6s., gave twenty-three guineas. This sent some of the people almost off their heads; but when the uproar had ceased promises came thick and fast. Six, five, four, three guineas, and sums ranging from sixpence, soon brought up a grand total promised (and some paid) in that meeting of over 120l. Our people have given altogether about 420l., which for us is very good, we think.

The Rev. W. J. Elliott writes from Lagos High School: "At the close of our half-year's work in June all the schools were care-

fully examined, the elementary day school by the native ministers, assisted by the head master, and the high school, male and female, myself. All passed off very satisfactorily, many of the pupils acquitting themselves very creditably indeed. This is the more encouraging, as we are all round considerably undermanned. As Ministers, we have just been relieved of a little of the burden which has from the beginning lain upon our shoulders, the Circuit having undertaken the entire responsibility of maintaining the elementary schools, and appointed a school board, or committee, to manage them, of course under our constant supervision as heretofore; but we have no anxiety as to the 'ways and means.' The attendance is increasing, and we expect a great influx, as the people begin to feel that the schools are their own, and that by supporting them they are helping themselves.', 'last_edit_date': '1881-01-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1881#article-26', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.678, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'EDUCATION OF FEMALES IN AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The *Church Missionary Record*, giving account of the erection of an edifice, at the cost of 2,500l., for a female boarding-school at Sierra Leone, the money being an anonymous gift of a gentleman in England for that especial purpose, says truly: "The educational process is going on amongst the men; that of females must keep pace with it, else disastrous consequences must ensue. As Mr. Nicol well observes, 'the proper training of the young generation now will be conducive to the progress of religion and civilization in Africa. Africa must be regenerated by Africans themselves.'" How strong an appeal this in favour of Mrs. Moseley's Industrial Female School for Cape Coast! We most earnestly desire to see that fund completed. Mrs. Moseley ought to leave England in October on her work of love and mercy. Would that some of our friends whom God has abundantly blessed would come forward with the really small amount now wanting to make up the required sum!', 'last_edit_date': '1867-08-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_08_1867#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.675, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'AFRICAN SUBSCRIPTIONS TO THE AFRICAN-AID SOCIETY', 'section_title': '', 'content': "In our closing number for 1864 we stated the necessity of increased funds, if the Society is to fight the battle of African civilization before the committee of the House of Commons during the coming session of Parliament. It has been a cause of great satisfaction to us to receive the above donations from M'Carthy's Island; and these, too, spontaneously collected by Dr. Horton before our remarks of last month had reached the Gambia. It is an encouraging fact that, with one or two exceptions, such as the Commandant, &c., all the contributors are Africans. We cannot too strongly urge upon the Africans in every part of West Africa to which this journal penetrates, that all our efforts are directed to procuring for them increased facilities and protection—for advancing their interests and the Christian civilization of their native countries. Doctor Horton suggests in his letter that the Africans on the Coast ought to contribute the 200l. a-year which the Society requires in order to give it sufficient freedom of action. If all the native traders down the Coast would make it a personal affair; if every one would for himself determine to be an annual subscriber of, say, only one guinea to the Society, and to send this subscription forward regularly, we should indeed feel stimulated anew, and powerfully stimulated, to increased exertions for them. It will be a proud day for us when we can say to the English friends of Africa, as well as to the revilers of Africa, that the African-Aid Society has an African list of subscribers, whose annual contributions render it independent of lukewarm European sympathies. Such a position would greatly strengthen our hands, both with the British Government and the British public. It will do much for us to be able to show them an educated Africa, keenly alive to its responsibilities towards those from among whom they have been brought out by the education they have received—fully alive to the necessity of those ameliorations of Government system, and those increased facilities for the development of African resources, for which we, in their interest, have ever been contending. We write freely, because we do not want one penny of their money for ourselves—but only for those disbursements necessarily attendant on public action. All we do for them is done gratuitously, in the hope of advancing God's cause in the world—and all we ask from them in return is to evince their sense of the importance and utility of our services—of those services which have really now given to West Africa a voice and a representation in Europe—by relieving us from the painful necessity of having to ask from others the small amount necessary to cover the unavoidable expenses incurred in thus serving them. If some leading native trader at each trading station, or town, or river along the West Coast, would organise the work among his fellow-traders, all that is wanted might speedily be accomplished.", 'last_edit_date': '1865-01-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1865#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.687, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Progress of the Universities’ Mission to Central Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The first idea of a mission was started, in response to an earnest appeal made by Dr. Livingstone, at a meeting at Cambridge, in 1857. It may be regarded as having been formally instituted at a second meeting at Cambridge, on the 1st of November, 1859. The first head of the Mission was Bishop Mackenzie, who established a station at Magomero, on the River Shiri, where a large settlement of slaves, liberated by the Mission party, was formed under the guidance of Dr. Livingstone. The appeal proceeds with a summary of the work that is being done by the Mission at the present time. 1. On the site of the old slave market at Zanzibar, purchased by the liberality of the Rev. A. N. West, of Pembroke College, who died whilst in sole charge of the Mission, Christmas-day, 1874, a fine church which is far advanced towards completion. Adjoining it the Bishop hopes soon to erect houses for the clergy and mission workers, schools, and a hospital. 2. At Mbweni, four miles from Zanzibar, a settlement of adult liberated slaves has been formed, and attached to this station is a girls’ school. 3. At Kiungani, two miles from Zanzibar, is a large boys’ industrial school, which is partly self-supporting. Much of the carpenter’s and other work for the fabric of the Zanzibar church has been done here. 4. A house in Zanzibar was opened as a hospital on Dec. 12, 1875, upon the arrival of Miss Allen and two nurses. It has already done excellent service. 5. Magila, the Mission station on the mainland, is in charge of the Rev. J. P. Farler and Mr. Moss, and has lately been reinforced by Mr. Clarke; the reports are favourable. Bishop Steere has just returned to Zanzibar after five months’ absence on an expedition to the Nyassa country. The details of this interesting journey, begun from Linoi (a point some distance south of Zanzibar, and the nearest part of the coast to Lake Nyassa), at the end of last October, and completed Jan. 21, 1876, will be found in a pamphlet printed at Zanzibar, and now issued under the title of “A Walk to the Nyassa Country.” This suggests the feasibility of extending the operations of the Mission over 300 miles or upwards on the mainland in the direction of the country first occupied under Bishop Mackenzie towards Lake Nyassa. It also affords convincing evidence of the existence still of the slave-trade in the number of caravans which were met. It reveals likewise, incidentally, the self-devotion and perseverance of the Bishop, who when the European members of his party failed him through ill health, started on the journey with native bearers only. The Bishop estimates that by this means some 10,000 slaves were conveyed to the coast. By God’s providence the journey was, notwithstanding difficulties and privations, accomplished safely. In a letter recently addressed by Bishop Steere to the members of the Universities of Oxford and Cambridge, he says: “I have just returned from a walk of some 700 miles, through almost unknown country, undertaken in your name and for your honour. I have agreed with the greatest of the native chiefs (Mataka) near the Lake Nyassa for a site and for countenance in our mission. I find that my appeal for personal help is being nobly responded to. We paid during the year 20 outward passages. I hear of four more, perhaps now on their way, and of others pressing to follow them. . . . There remain 14 of us, mostly young students, out of whom I feel no doubt the most efficient missionaries will ultimately be formed. Not one of my helpers is desiring money profit from his work. So, then, I feel sure that, if not the Universities, the English Church will find us the men and women we need.', 'last_edit_date': '1876-05-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1876#article-20', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.673, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'AFRICA AND THE JUBILEE FUND OF THE WESLEYAN MISSIONARY SOCIETY', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Wesleyan Missionary Society have raised a large Jubilee Fund at Leeds, and other towns. We are glad to see that a prominent place is given to Africa and her children in the contemplated disposal of it. The following is from the monthly organ of the Society: "It was deeply felt by the Committee that the hope for the evangelization of Africa must mainly rest on the employment of a native agency. The difficulties of the African languages form a barrier to the free labour of English missionaries among the African nations, and the climate of large portions of that vast continent is very unfavourable to European health and life. At the same time, on every mission in Western and in Southern Africa there have been found native converts who have been deemed suitable to be employed as teachers among their countrymen. Some of these have been honoured of God with great success. It is desired that means may be provided for the training and employment of a much larger number of native African agents; and that at important centres, hereafter to be selected, schools or institutions should be formed for that purpose, to be commenced and sustained by an appropriation from the Jubilee Fund. In contemplation of the vastness of the field of labour in Africa it will be admitted that a large amount may with propriety be consecrated to this service.', 'last_edit_date': '1863-11-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1863#article-23', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.702, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'LIBERIA COLLEGE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We are glad to see that higher education is making progress in Liberia. The following from the *Observer*, extracted from a "Circular," is of interest, and appeals strongly to the friends of Africa:—

"It is now proposed to take a new departure. It is expected that students will avail themselves of the advantages of the college not only from all parts of the Republic, but from other settlements along the coast, and from the tribes in the interior. In respect to funds, the trustees feel that in view of the increased work which lies before them, they will urgently need far larger pecuniary assistance than the institution has yet had. Increased endowments are necessary to enable the institution to hold its position and fulfil its functions as a college. It is the object of the trustees to encourage and assist needy boys, who give promise of usefulness, especially from among the aborigines, to obtain a liberal education. To this end they earnestly solicit the establishment of permanent scholarships. Professorships of Ancient Languages and Mathematics are provided for. There is urgent need now for endowments of Professorships in the departments of the Moral and Physical Sciences, of Jurisprudence, and of Arabic and the Native vernaculars. . . . No provision is at present made for boarding the students in the college building; but board may be had in respectable families in the neighbourhood of the College, at prices varying from ten to twelve dollars, or from 2l. to 2l. 10s. per month. The charges for one year, for students from abroad, including all expenses, will vary from 150 to 200 dols., or from 30l. to 40l. sterling, according to the disposition of the students."', 'last_edit_date': '1881-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1881#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.683, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Collection of Funds at Cape Coast for the African-Aid Society', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We understand that our friends at Cape Coast have, at the instance of one of our valued correspondents, put down their names as donors to the African-Aid Society for sums amounting in all to £67. 1s. 3d.; but, although earnestly pressed for payment to send their voluntary subscriptions, only 41. 17s. 3d. of the amount had been collected up to the departure of the mail on the 17th March.

The African-Aid Society and the African Times are certainly entitled to all the money aid that Africans can give, but necessarily, also, to such considerable personal sacrifices, as their experience goes to provide for somebody to must pay, if the work we have in hand for Africa is to be completed. And we call earnestly, therefore, upon all Africans especially who desire the prosperity and advancement of their country, and an increase of respect for themselves, to pay where they have promised as assistance, and hold to the promise and pay where they have not yet done so. People who will not help for their own good do really sin against themselves.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-04-24', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/24_04_1865#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.669, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African-Aid Society and the Missionary Societies', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'No one, we think, who has attentively considered the subject of missionary effort in native Africa, can have remained blind to the fact of the great obstacles placed in the way of such noble efforts, by the total absence among the African populations of those facilities for action which the accessories of an extensive commerce and of civilised rule, present to the missionary in almost all other great fields of missionary labour in heathen lands. The African-Aid Society acts, therefore, as the pioneer of Christian missions, in its endeavours to remove those exceptional obstacles, which not only add very much to the expense of those missions, and to the privations and dangers of the devoted missionaries, but limit also the extension of those missions, and retard their great work of the proclamation of the glad tidings of salvation, the acceptance of which can alone remove the bleeding woes of Africa. We feel that the African-Aid Society cannot have a more glorious title than that of "THE PIONEER OF CHRISTIAN MISSIONS AND OF CIVILISING COMMERCE." It is in this capacity of pioneer that the efforts of the society have been so much directed toward the Gambia and the Sherboro countries, and toward our Gold Coast possessions, Dahomey, and the districts in which the great river Niger presents a path for missionary and commercial action. It is as a "pioneer" that it waits, and watches, and acts (so far as circumstances will permit) for the removal or modification of those deep curses to Eastern Africa, the Portuguese rule from Delagoa Bay to the territories of Zanzibar, and the connivance of the Sultan of the latter, for pecuniary considerations, at that devastating slave-trade carried on by the Arabs with the Persian Gulf. What a field of arduous labour is here presented to the Christian view—is here placed before the philanthropist, the statesman, and the merchant. And are we not justified in saying that it is a disgrace to a Christian and enlightened country and people—a country and a people whom God has specially entrusted with the work of the spread of the Gospel of Christ and of true civilization among the nations—that such a work should languish for want of a very moderate degree of encouragement and support? Is it surprising that we should have echoed the complaint and the appeal of the Archbishop of York—that we, who feel ourselves highly honoured and greatly privileged by God in being permitted to give a portion of our most earnest energies to this "pioneer" work for Him, and for those whom He has made of one blood with us (though so differing in colour and other accidents), should lament the apathy which hinders us, and remind our fellow-subjects of that great duty which especially devolves upon them and upon us, as the descendants of those who for so many years perpetrated and permitted the African slave-trade,
Page 65', 'last_edit_date': '1864-11-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1864#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.672, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Tribute to the African-Aid Society', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'WE have been often rather tauntingly asked what the African-Aid Society is really effecting. Because querists could not see in our columns that the Society had sent "—emigrants to Africa on board the ship —," &c., they refused to comprehend that a great work was advancing under our hands. They forgot that one of our great objects is to prepare Africa for that influx of colonial civilization which will one day come in to accelerate her progress, as well as to help to bring in that coloured civilization to a home and a mission in Africa.

Under these circumstances, the letter from Anamaboe, which we now publish, is doubly gratifying to us. We offer our grateful thanks to our Gold Coast and other African friends for that and other evidences which we are now receiving of their appreciation of the benefits we are conferring upon Africa. We know that, if only adequately supported, we shall, within the next few years, be able, by God's help and blessing, to produce results in

**NOVEMBER 23, 1863.**

Africa that half a century, without the African-Aid Society or a similar organization, would not have witnessed.

The following is the letter above referred to:—

**TO THE PRESIDENT AND MEMBERS OF THE AFRICAN-AID SOCIETY,  
8, ADELPHI-TERRACE, LONDON.**

Anamaboe, Gold Coast.

Gentlemen,—The immense good which the African-Aid Society has done for the Coast of Africa since their formation is a thing that is universally acknowledged by every African on the Coast. Through it the poorest man here has a means by which his grievances can be made known, and the want of the whole country properly represented in influential quarters; and I am sure that by the effectual organization of the African-Aid Society many valuable measures which have been proposed to the Government, having for object the raising of Africa from its degradation, but which have been squashed by Europeans on the Coast, who are dead against every measure having such tendency, will soon be so represented, that the Government will not hesitate to carry them into effect.

I am unable to express to you how grateful we are for what you have hitherto done; your Society is a necessity to Africa—a vital and indispensable one—and your existence will always ensure real, deep, and important improvements in Africa.

Truly satisfied of the inestimable benefit we have derived from the African-Aid Society and its valuable paper, I have endeavoured to urge their support not only amongst my countrymen, but also amongst Europeans, and request them to subscribe liberally to both; and I have improved the opportunity I lately had of visiting Cape Coast by calling upon each gentleman and asking his support. I am happy to state that they gave liberally towards my appeal. The only unfortunate circumstance is that the war has destroyed the country, and there is no trade whatever, or I might have been able to forward you more. I hope you will acknowledge the subscriptions in the African Times.', 'last_edit_date': '1863-11-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1863#article-19', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.669, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Mission Work at the Cameroons', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'in the printing-office are not recognized by the other missionaries, excepting the one under whose direction he labours. Why so? Because ministerial discord and dissension are at the bottom of it. One of England's greatest philanthropists said that, "If Africa is to be evangelised she must be evangelised by her sons." Of course, not exclusive of the aid of England's sons, but a black ministry with one or two whites at its head will be found more effectual than otherwise. The following fact will be seen to give much force to this suggestion. White missionaries are obliged very frequently to go to Europe to recruit their health, no doubt at a heavy cost to the Society, to say nothing of the disadvantage that their stations must suffer owing to their absence, which sometimes is rather protracted. The two oldest missionaries in the mission now, excepting the superintendent, are blacks. One has been out twenty-five years, and the other twelve years, yet they have not once had occasion to go to Jamaica to recruit their health; whereas the whites, without exception, have found it necessary to go to England, some at rather short intervals. Should the question be asked, "Why are not some youths taken out of the day-schools at Cameroons and Victoria, and sent to England, or even to the Sierra Leone Grammar School, to be trained up as teachers and native preachers?" or "Why cannot a boarding school be established at Victoria?" the answer, no doubt, will be, "Oh, it will cost the Society a very large amount of money." Undoubtedly true; but isn't it a generally acknowledged fact, and don't we ourselves know it from experience, that it is always best, in the long run, to purchase things at wholesale prices? A wholesale purchase may entail on the purchaser a heavy expense at once, but in the end it will be found far cheaper than purchasing at retail prices. Victoria is a cheap place—food and fish so very plentiful that the missionaries up here send all the way down there very often to buy food, which requires only tobacco and salt to buy it with, and which can be had every day. Victoria being a market town, a boarding school once established there, with competent teachers and a constant supply of books and other requisites to be sold to the pupils of the school, will, in the course of a few years, supply the different stations in the mission with young men capable of taking schools and churches under their own care, and in this way the work of evangelisation will be more surely and steadily carried on, and the Society's labours and expenses be more than amply rewarded; also, in course of time, the school will become a self-supporting school.', 'last_edit_date': '1869-07-28', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1869#article-21', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.674, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE ACTION OF THE AFRICAN-AID SOCIETY.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Africa, anything beyond the mere egotism of surface philanthropy, it will find fresh support. If it ever perish for want of it, while, as now, faithful in its mission, disgrace to those who shall have allowed it to perish. And here we must say one word to the educated Africans of the West Coast. They have recognised, and are recognising, by their subscriptions to this paper, the importance to them of the African Times. But they have not as yet done anything for the support of The Society whose influence makes that journal a power. In future every subscription will be published in this paper. Every educated and commercial African ought to feel that this society is his. The name of every one ought to be found year by year in the list of its annual subscribers. There are hundreds who can afford their one or two guineas a-year. It is only thus they can show that they recognise the important efforts of this society for them and for their race and country; thus only they can show that they are alive to the vast benefits of the civilization of which they have themselves become partakers. It was for this that we hailed with peculiar satisfaction the annual subscription of the Rev. Mr. Robbin, Colonial Chaplain at the Gambia, as announced in our last. His worthy and honoured name stands first on the list of our African subscribers. We hope, for the credit of the educated Africans, that it is but the first of hundreds. hh: Religious establishments in Africa, supported by both local communities and colonial authorities, played a significant role in education and charity through collaborative efforts and government grants.
result: The observations from both the "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles collectively support the claim that religious establishments in Africa, backed by local communities and colonial authorities, played a significant role in education and charity through collaborative efforts and government grants. The textbook highlights the role of Christian missions in establishing schools and promoting education as a means of evangelization, with colonial governments providing grants-in-aid, particularly in Southern Africa where missionary activities led to the creation of elementary, secondary, and teacher-training institutions. Local African initiatives, such as those by Gikuyu cultural nationalists and local rulers in Uganda and Southern Nigeria, also contributed to educational expansion. The involvement of black missionaries and Afro-Brazilian communities further illustrates the collaborative nature of these efforts. However, the textbook notes that educational services during colonial times were often inadequate and unevenly distributed, primarily benefiting white settlers and administrators, indicating a disparity between the claim and historical reality. Similarly, The African Times articles mention that Wesleyan and Roman Catholic missions received government allowances for education and charity, with religious societies like the Church Missionary Society and the Wesleyan Missionary Society establishing schools in West Africa. These societies collaborated with local communities, as seen in the efforts of Bishop Crowther in Bonny and Rev. George Nicol in the Gambia, who raised local funds for school chapels and mission houses. The articles also emphasize the need for greater government support, criticizing its inadequacy and suggesting that reliance on missionary efforts was insufficient. Together, these sources illustrate the significant yet complex role of religious establishments in education and charity, facilitated by both local and colonial support, while acknowledging the limitations and inequalities in these efforts.

Additionally, local African initiatives also contributed to the spread of education, as seen in the efforts of Gikuyu cultural nationalists and local rulers in Uganda and Southern Nigeria. The text also notes the involvement of black missionaries and Afro-Brazilian communities in educational and religious activities, further illustrating the collaborative nature of these efforts. However, the text also points out that the educational services provided during colonial times were often inadequate and unevenly distributed, primarily benefiting white settlers and administrators. This highlights a difference between the claim and the historical reality, as the support from colonial authorities was not always equitable or sufficient for the broader African population. Overall, the text supports the claim by demonstrating the significant role of religious establishments in education and charity, facilitated by both local and colonial support, while also acknowledging the limitations and inequalities present in these efforts.

Additionally, the articles highlight the involvement of religious societies, such as the Church Missionary Society and the Wesleyan Missionary Society, in establishing schools and promoting education in West Africa.
